body_text.text: Tatyana A. Bairova, Oksana A. Ershova, Lubov V. Rychkova, Sergey I. Kolesnikov, Lubov I Kolesnikova Scientific Сentre for Family Health and Human Reproduction Problems, Irkutsk, Russia
body_text.section: Prevalence of mutation C60T gene mitochondrial superoxide dismutase among Caucasian and Mongoloid adolescents

body_text.text: The gene SOD2 determines activity of superoxide dismutase 2 SOD2. Mutation C60T localizes in the gene SOD2. This mutation determines the change in the interaction of protein SOD2 subunits. This leads to a decrease in SOD2 enzyme activity. No information on prevalence of mutation in gene SOD2 among different races was found. The aim of this project was to study prevalence of mutations in gene SOD2 in different races. One hundred and nineteen healthy adolescents aged 14-17 years were studied: 65 Caucasians (Russians, mean age 15.02 AE 0.98 years) and 54 Mongoloids (Buryats, mean age 15.31 AE 0.96 years). All adolescents lived on the Asian territory of Russia. Peripheral blood was obtained for DNA isolation. The C60T mutation gene SOD was genotyped. We found in group of Caucasian adolescents the frequencies of CC, CT and TT genotypes: 87.7%, 7.7%, 4.6% respectively. The frequency of the mutant T-allele was 8.5%. In the Buryat adolescents we identified only the CC -genotype carriers (100%). The frequency of the mutant T-allele was 0%. Thus, the C60T mutation of the SOD2 gene was found in the Caucasian adolescents. Carriers of the mutant T-allele were not identified among the Buryat adolescents. 16. The relationship of SOD2 gene C60T mutation with activity of superoxide dismutase Tatyana A. Bairova, Oksana A. Ershova, Lubov V. Rychkova, Ludmila A. Grebenkina, Marina A. Darenskaya, Lubov I Kolesnikova Scientific Сentre for Family Health and Human Reproduction Problems, Irkutsk, Russia SOD2 gene determines the activity of the enzyme superoxide dismutase 2. Nowadays we have known polymorphisms and mutations of the SOD2 gene including the C60T mutation. No information on the role of C60T mutation SOD2 gene in the variability of superoxide dismutase 2 activities is found. We analyzed the activity of superoxide dismutase 2 in adolescents with and without C60T mutation of the SOD2 gene. The study included 65 healthy Caucasian adolescents. All adolescents lived on the Asian territory of Russia. The ethnicity data were collected by interviewing using a questionnaire including data on the nationality of their ancestors to the third generation. Peripheral blood was obtained for DNA isolation. Genotyping was performed for C60T gene SOD. Activity of superoxide dismutase 2 was determined by fluorometric method. We found in carriers of the CC -genotype SOD2 gene activity of superoxide dismutase was 1.56 arb. units (1.43-1.65); in carriers of the CTgenotype SOD2 gene was 1.36 arb. units (1.25-1.57) and in carriers of the TT -genotype SOD2 gene was 1.83 arb. units (1.54-1.85) (p>0,05). Thus, we have not found activity differences of the superoxide dismutase in carriers of mutant T allele of C60T mutation SOD2 gene.

body_text.text: Hydrogen peroxide, generated in numerous biological processes, has been implicated in metabolic and regulatory functions. This redox metabolite can diffuse across cells and tissues and initiate cellular responses, thus acting as an important transcription-independent signaling molecule. As a signaling molecule its concentration increases only slightly from steady-state levels (10-100 nM), yet much higher levels can be measured during pathological stress. Real time extracellular monitoring of resting and rapid changes of H O 2 in the nanomolar range in complex biological media is demanding and requires the design of (bio) sensors with high sensitivity, selectivity, low limit of detection and rapid response time. Detection of H 2 O 2 based on electrochemical sensors is attractive because these can be used in diverse biological preparations, ranging from cell cultures to ex vivo (slices, biopsies and biological fluids) and in vivo applications (implantable sensors). Here we have designed, characterized and evaluated novel sensing strategies using microelectrodes, and screenprinting electrodes for detection and monitoring of H 2 O 2 in diverse biological preparations. We have explored surface modification strategies such as electrodeposition of platinum nanoparticles and hexacyanoferrate mediators to attain high selectivity and sensitivity measurements of H 2 O 2 . Supported by FEDER funds through COMPETE and by FCT under the project POCI-01-0145-FEDER-028261.

body_text.text: The creation of the Permanent Space Stations, has highlighted some harmful effects of the absence of weight on human health, since some physiological systems can alter temporarily or permanently.Technology allowed the creation of machines able to simulate on earth the reduction of gravity (microgravity), to investigate this condition on organs and tissues. Currently, the knowledge about the effects of microgravity on human skin, the first and most important barrier involved in homeostasis and defense of the organism, has been little investigated. So, we decided to study the effects of microgravity on human keratinocytes. They were placed on a Random Positioning Machine (RPM), inside a humidified incubator (5% CO 2 at 37 C) for increasing times. Treated keratinocytes were distinguished by a set of core features associated with senescence cell damage that become more evident depending on the duration of the test. In particular, microgravity affects cells proliferation and morphology and induces the secretion of cytokines, (i.e. IL1α, IL 6 and IL8), that are a part of the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP) . Moreover, electrophysiological approach shows the ability of microgravity to decrease total membrane current. In conclusion, our work suggests an effect of microgravity on keratinocytes that deserves to be investigated. Nitric oxide is a key-player in cellular redox signaling. Its addition onto cysteines thiols, the S-nitrosylation (SNO), is involved in many biochemical and physiological processes [1] . The regulation mechanisms induced by this post-translational modification and their implications in cancer are intense matter of research. Thousands of proteins undergo Snitrosylation, and its dysregulation is implicated in many diseases including cancer [2] . The elucidation of molecular mechanisms underpinning regulation by SNO is essential to open avenues for cancer therapies. Albeit molecular modeling is known to be a powerful tool in such context, redox regulation by SNO has been widely underappreciated by the computational community. We seek to unveil the molecular mechanisms linked to protein regulation by S-nitrosylation. Using computational chemistry methods, we investigated the structure of a cancer-related kinase, c-Src, known to be activated upon SNO [3] . Long-range communication paths between amino acids play here a major role. The target cysteine being conserved, this regulation mechanism might be conserved throughout the Src family kinases. EB and EP are grateful to the Benzon foundation and to the COM-PUTEROME infrastructure. 1 Furuta 2017

body_text.text: Institute of Pharmaceutical Sciences, University of Graz, Austria.
body_text.section: Valery Bochkov

body_text.text: Oxidized phospholipids (OxPLs) represent an emerging class of lipid mediators generated by enzymatic or non-enzymatic oxidation of esterified polyunsaturated fatty acids. Multiple studies have characterized OxPLs as inducers of proinflammatory, procoagulant and proangiogenic mediators in a variety of cells and tissues. Accumulating evidence suggests that OxPLs induce these proteins through signaling pathways that are different from those utilized by the majority of physiological inducers of inflammation, blood clotting and angiogenesis. Selective inhibition of these OxPLs-specific signaling pathways potentially can prevent development of pathology without impairing normal physiological processes.This presentation will discuss specific intracellular signaling mechanisms mediating induction of interleukin-8, tissue factor and VEGF by OxPLs. As a proof of principle for selective inhibition of OxPL-induced inflammation a new chemical scaffold will be described that selectively inhibits production of interleukin-8 by OxPLs but has minimal effects on the action of innate immune mediators and agonists such as cytokines (TNFa, IL-1β) or bacterial products (lipopolysaccharide). The study suggests new approaches for pharmacological protection against oxidative stress using non-antioxidant compounds.
body_text.section: Valery Bochkov

body_text.text: Glioblastoma multiforme is the most aggressive and common form of malignant gliomas and often demonstrates resistance to chemotherapy. As a result of elevated ROS production, cancer cells rely heavily on antioxidant systems to keep redox homeostasis. The thioredoxin and glutaredoxin/glutathione systems regulate oxidative stress being determinant for cell survival and proliferation. Mercury compounds have been shown to target quite effectively the thioredoxin system. Thus, the aim of this study is to test the effects of two mercury compounds, thimerosal (TM) and ethylmercury (EtHg) in human glioblastoma cells in comparison to temozolamide (TMZ) frequently used in chemotherapy. Cell viability of U87 cells was measured in the presence of EtHg and TM by MTT assay and after 24h the GI50 was approximately 13 μM. Following exposure of cells to EtHg and TM (5, 10 e 15 μm) TrxR and Trx activity decreased very significantly in cytosol and mitochondria. GSH levels were evaluated by the DTNB assay and GPx by the NADPH-consumption assay. Expression of TrxR, Trx and GPx was evaluated in whole-cell lysates by Western Blot. Overall, results indicate that Hg compounds alone and combined with TMZ constitute a promising therapeutic tool to tackle antioxidant defenses and overcame tumors therapy resistance. This work is funded by FCT -Portugal through projects PTDC/MED-FAR/ 31136/2017 and by iMed.ULisboa UID/DTP/04138/2013 both from FCT.
body_text.section: Valery Bochkov

body_text.text: 27. The role of vitamins, coenzymes and their synthetic derivatives in regulating free-radical processes involving biomolecules S. Brinkevich and O. Shadyro Belarusian State University.
body_text.section: Valery Bochkov

body_text.text: ROS-induced reactions involving biomolecules are known to cause damage to the latter with possible formation of new bioactive compounds. Of numerous homolytic processes in which biologically relevant compounds can participate, the most thoroughly studied ones were oxidation reactions. Activation of such processes may trigger onset and development of many pathologic conditions, which determined the therapeutic use of antioxidants and vitamins C, E, P etc. in medical practice. We have found that, on interaction with ROS bioorganic compounds underwent fragmentation reactions without O participation. These reactions caused damage to lipids, nucleosides, amino acids and their derivatives. During these processes, compounds were formed playing crucial role in signaling, such as phosphatidic acid and ceramides. It has been established that quinones and substances containing in their structures a carbonyl group conjugated with the >C¼C< bond effectively blocked the above-named fragmentation reactions. This substance group includes coenzyme Q, vitamins B, C, P, K and related compounds. In this report, the data will be discussed enabling correlations to be outlined between structures of vitamins or coenzymes and their ability to regulate various free-radical processes in biosystems.
body_text.section: Valery Bochkov

body_text.text: 28. Does myeloperoxidase-induced modification of extracellular matrix (ECM) of the arterial wall contribute to vulnerable atherosclerotic plaques?
body_text.section: Valery Bochkov

body_text.text: Huan Cai, Christine Y. Chuang, and Michael J. Davies Dept. of Biomedical Sciences, Panum Institute, Copenhagen, Denmark.
body_text.section: Valery Bochkov

body_text.text: Introduction: The extracellular matrix (ECM) is vital for maintaining the functional and mechanical properties of arteries. We hypothesised that the myeloperoxidase (MPO)-generated inflammatory oxidant hypochlorous acid (HOCl) would affect native human coronary artery smooth muscle cell (HCASMC)-derived ECM, and contribute to ECM damage and vulnerable atherosclerotic plaques. Methods: ECM laid down by HCASMCs was decellularized and exposed to a MPO system (0-200 μM H 2 O 2 /200 mM Cl -/20 nM MPO). Localization of MPO and ECM proteins was detected by confocal microscopy. ECM damage was investigated using antibodies against specific ECM proteins via ELISA, immunoblotting and immunofluorescence. Results: MPO is shown to bind preferentially to the matrix glycoprotein fibronectin, and initiates HOCl generation and ECM damage in a dosedependent manner. ECM modifications were detected with 10 μM or greater H 2 O 2 . MPO is shown to have a higher affinity for oxidized ECM than the parent material. Conclusions: These experiments show that MPO binds avidly to the ECM and generates damage via formation of HOCl using pathophysiological concentrations of H 2 O 2 . This damage promotes further MPO binding and rationalizes the accumulation of oxidative modifications on the ECM with age and disease. This damage is proposed to contribute to the formation of vulnerable plaques in atherosclerosis.
body_text.section: Valery Bochkov

body_text.text: Cochlear implants (CI) are electronic devices suitable to replace the Organ of Corti in adults or children with severe/profound sensorineural hearing loss. Unfortunately, the insertion of CI electrodes may negatively affect inner ear tissues, causing apoptosis and/or necrosis in inner ear cells and seriously interfering with hearing loss recovery. In this study, we tested the biocompatibility of two types of nanoparticles, respectively based on lithium niobate and barium titanate, which could be used to produce innovative CI electrodes, more biocompatible and more efficient in sound transduction. The biocompatibility of nanoparticles was evaluated based on cell viability, cell morphology and expression of an apoptotic marker, and by evaluation of production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in an inner ear cell line (OC-k3) derived from the Immortomouse® Organ of Corti. The results showed that nanoparticles based on barium titanate slightly reduced cell viability at high doses (50 μM, 500 μM, 1000 μM) up to 48h while those based on lithium niobate induced a significant increase at 72h from treatment. Both types of nanoparticles did not induce changes in cell morphology, cytochrome C distribution and ROS production. The results encouraged the use of these nanoparticles to develop new and improved CI electrodes.
body_text.section: Biocompatibility of two types of nanoparticles in an inner ear cell line

body_text.text: Luke Carroll, Shuwen Jiang, Michael Davies
body_text.section: Oxidation of disulfide bonds leads to protein glutathionylation

body_text.text: Glutathionylation is a key process in redox cell signalling, and has previously been thought to occur only at free Cys residues via oxidative mechanisms. However, disulfides, which comprise of two covalently linked Cys residues are also a target for oxidants, with their reactivity varying greatly depending on the disulfide environment. Exposure of disulfide containing proteins to oxidants results in the incorporation of oxygen, consistent with the formation of thiosulfinates or related species. Subsequent addition of GSH decreases oxygen content and results in the adduction of GSH to the protein as assessed by immunoblotting and mass spectrometry. Increasing incubation time post-oxidant exposure results in a decrease in glutathionylation, consistent with the formation of a reactive intermediate species on the protein by the oxidant. This appears to be a general oxidation reaction for disulfides as a wide range of oxidants are capable of inducing GSHylation of disulfide-containing proteins including hypochlorous acid, peroxynitrous acid, singlet oxygen and hydrogen peroxide. The oxidation of disulfide bonds therefore represents a novel mechanism for the glutathionylation of proteins, which may play an important role in cell signalling.
body_text.section: University of Copenhagen, Denmark

body_text.text: C. Cervellati 1 , A. Passaro , V. Rosta 1 , G.B. Vigna 3 , I. Crivellari 1 , J.M. Sanz 2 , F. Zimetti 4 , E. Dalla Nora 3 , G. Zuliani , G. Valacchi , T. Bellini 1 , A. Trentini The skin is the main organs exposed to airborne particulate matter (PM) . In this work, we analyzed the proinflammatory and oxidative effects of PM components on inflammatory responses. We investigated four redoxactive chemicals, such Cu (II) metal and quinones generated by atmospheric oxidation or cellular metabolic processes from polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs); 9,10 phenanthrenequinone and naphthoquinone 1,2-NQN and 1,4-NQN. We performed in vitro tests on human keratinocyte (HaCaT) cells and also acellular assays based on the oxidation of dithiothreitol and ascorbic acid antioxidants to assess the oxidative potential (OP). We found that the treated keratinocytes showed increased activation of NFκB and increased levels of IL8 gene expression. Moreover, the treatment with Cu (II) and quinones increased the activities and expression of specific redox response genes, SOD1 and GPX. Finally, we found an induced alteration of the mitochondrial ultrastructure and apoptosis after 24 h. Our results suggest that the pollutant components are able to modulate signal transduction pathways, the activation of inflammatory and oxidative damage in the skin. Altogether these observations indicate that exposure of skin to air pollutants modifies the redox equilibrium of keratinocytes, which could explain the increased skin damage observed in populations that live in high-pollution cities.
body_text.section: Potential impact of paraoxonase-1 and myeloperoxidase on action and quality of HDL

body_text.text: 33. Biochemical mechanisms of the anti-obesity effect of an ursolic acid-enriched extract of Cynomorium songaricum in high fat diet-induced obese mice HCY2, an ursolic acid-enriched extract of Cynomorii Herba, has been shown to significantly reduce body weight gain and the weight of white fat pads in various adipose tissues as well as attenuate indices of the associated metabolic syndrome, namely, hyperglycemia, glucose intolerance, dyslipidemia and fatty liver in high-fat diet (HFD)-fed mice. The current study demonstrated that the weight reduction produced by HCY2 is associated with activation of the AMPK signalling pathway with resultant increases in mitochondrial biogenesis and mitochondrial uncoupling in skeletal muscle in vivo. A recoupler, ketocholestanol, was used to explore the possible role of mitochondrial uncoupling in the antiobesity effect afforded by HCY2 in HFD-fed mice. Taken together, our results suggest that HCY2 may be proved to be useful for the prevention and/or treatment of obesity and related metabolic disorders. The denitrosylase S-nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR) has been suggested to sustain mitochondrial removal by autophagy (mitophagy), functionally linking S-nitrosylation to cell senescence and aging. In this study, we provide evidence that GSNOR is induced at the translational level in response to hydrogen peroxide and mitochondrial ROS. The use of selective pharmacological inhibitors and siRNAs demonstrate that GSNOR induction is an event downstream of the redox-mediated activation of ATM, which in turn phosphorylates CHK2 and p53 as intermediate players of this signaling axis. Changes in the levels of GSNOR, or the expression of a redox-insensitive form of ATM modulates cell sensitivity to oxidative stress, impacts mitophagy, and affects cell survival. Overall, our data place GSNOR as a crucial molecular player underlying the emerging antioxidant function of ATM.
body_text.section: Potential impact of paraoxonase-1 and myeloperoxidase on action and quality of HDL

body_text.text: Caio Fernando Ferreira Coêlho 1 , Vinicyus Teles Chagas , Ivana Letícia Santos Souza 1 , Nathalee Liberal Xavier Ribeiro 1 , Bruno Araújo Serra Pinto 1 , Lucas Martins França , Antonio Marcus de Andrade Paes Myricetin is a flavonoid reported in literature for its hypotriglyceridemic, hypoglycemic and anti-obesogenic properties. Considering that monosodium L-glutamate (MSG)-induced obese mice have been appointed as a useful model for NAFLD studies, our study aimed to investigate whether myricetin could ameliorate NAFLD in MSG mice. To test our hypothesis, newborn male Swiss mice were injected with MSG solution s.c. (4mg/kg/ day) on alternate days in the first 10 days of life (n¼16), control animals (n¼8) received 0.9% saline solution. Assessment of metabolic syndrome features was made every 30 days of life. After reaching 90 days of life, MSG mice were treated with either myricetin (50mg/kg/day) or vehicle for 6 weeks. At the end of treatment, mice were euthanized, blood samples were collected for biochemistry assessment and liver samples were collected for histopathologic analysis. Myricetin treatment did not change body mass and visceral and non-visceral adipose tissue depots. However, it attenuated hyperglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, insulin sensitivity, as compared to MSG untreated mice. Finally, myricetin treatment totally reverted the microvesicular stetosis observed in MSG mice. In conclusion, our data allow us to suggest that liver is a main target of myricetin, which would be a potential adjuvant for NAFLD treatment.
body_text.section: Myricetin reverts non-alcoholic fatty liver disease in MSGobese mice

body_text.text: Lucia Coppo, Arne Holmgren Division of Biochemistry, Department of Medical Biochemistry and Biophysics, Karolinska Institutet, Sweden A number of methods to measure different redox species have been developed but this additional value of redox-biomarkers is still not used as diagnostic tool. The limitations are often related to the expenses and the technical difficulties. Another unexplored part of the redox biology that share the same limitations is the role of redox proteins on cell surface and if they have an active role in redox signalling. Aim: To develop simple, rapid and highly sensitive methods to measure Thioredoxin, Trx, Thioredoxin Reductase, TrxR, Glutaredoxin, Grx, and Glutathione, GSH, in plasma, serum and cell surface. Results: -We have developed new fluorescent based assays for Grx and total-GSH that overcome the limitations of the established methods. We were able to detect Grx-activity at picomolar levels and total-GSH in μM range, using 3-10μl of plasma. -Trx: We optimized the Trx1 ELISA applying reducing conditions and we obtained a yield up to 10 times higher than the established assay. The method has been applied in different cohort of serum from Alzheimer's patients.

body_text.text: Rett syndrome (RTT) is a progressive neurodevelopmental disorder mainly caused by mutations in the X-linked MECP2 gene. RTT patients show multisystem disturbances associated with an OxInflammatory status. Inflammasomes are multi-protein complexes, responsible for host immune responses against pathogen infections and redox-related cellular stress. Assembly of NLRP3/ASC inflammasome triggers pro-caspase-1 activation, thus, resulting in IL-1β and IL-18 maturation. However, an aberrant activation of inflammasome system has been implicated in several human diseases.Our aim was to investigate the possible role of inflammasome in the chronic subclinical inflammatory condition typical of RTT, by analysing this complex in basal and lipopolysaccharide (LPS)þ ATP-stimulated primary fibroblasts, as well as in serum from RTT patients and healthy volunteers.RTT cells showed increased levels of nuclear NF-κB and cytosolic ASC proteins, pro-IL-1β mRNA, and NLRP3/ ASC interaction in basal condition, without any further response upon the LPSþATP stimuli. Moreover, augmented levels of circulating ASC and caspase-1 proteins were found in serum of RTT patients, which are likely able to amplify the inflammatory response. Taken together, our findings indicate that RTT patients exhibited a challenged inflammasome machinery at cellular and systemic level, which may feed and perpetuate the subclinical inflammatory state observed in the pathology.
body_text.section: Italy

body_text.text: 38. Glutathione transferase P1 and O2 polymorphisms might be risk determinants in heart failure caused by coronary artery disease Vesna Coric 1 , Natalija Odanovic 2 , Jelena Colic 3 , Dejan Simeunovic 4 , Tanja Radic 1 , Marija Matic 1 , Slavica Radovanovic 5 , Marija Pljesa Ercegovac 1 , Tatjana Simic 1,6 , Dragan Simic , Ana Savic-Radojevic Quercetin (3,3 1 ,4 1 ,5 1 -7-pentahydroxyflavone, QT) is one of the most common dietary flavonoids with promising activity in cancer prevention or treatment, moreover it scavenges free radicals and inhibits lipid peroxidation Topical application of QT is limited due to its low aqueous solubility and low in vivo absorption. To potentially solve these problems the preparation, characterization and in vitro release of novel vehicle able to transport QT such as monoolein aqueous dispersions (MAD) was studiedd. MAD were produced by emulsifying monoolein in water 1,2 . As emulsifier, sodium cholate was employed at two different concentration, namely 0.15% and 0.25% with respect to the total weight of the formulation. Cryo-TEM and X-rays gave information respectively of the general morphology and of the inner structural organization of the MAD. MAD015 were a mixture of vesicles and cubic structures, whilst MAD025 were mainly unilamellar vesicles. PCS and SdFFF showed a size around 200 nm and that QT is almost completely associated to the nanoparticles.

body_text.text: 41. High fat diet-induced obesity alters mitochondrial dynamics in mouse white adipose tissue: effects of anthocyanins A dynamic process of fusion and fission sustains mitochondria functionality. Excess nutrient availability can cause alterations in mitochondrial dynamics and function. This study investigated the potential alterations in mitochondrial dynamics occurring in subcutaneous white adipose tissue (sWAT) as a consequence of high fat diet (HF)-induced obesity in mice. The protective effects of anthocyanins (AC) supplementation was also characterized. C57BL/6J male mice were fed for 14 w control (C) or HF diets, with or without 40 mg AC/kg body weight (HFA). Transmission electron microscopy showed altered sWAT mitochondria morphology, with a large number of elongated mitochondria, in HF compared to C and HFA mice. Drp1, a cytosolic dynamin GTPase, is phosphorylated, recruited to the mitochondria, and bound to receptors (e.g. Mff, Fis1) to initiate fission. This can target damaged mitochondria for mitophagy, which involves Parkin and NIX. Total Drp1, Fis1, Mff, Parkin and NIX content; and Drp1 phosphorylation (Ser 616) levels were markedly lower in HF sWAT compared to controls. AC prevented the decrease in Drp1, Drp1 phosphorylation, Parkin and NIX levels. Results suggest that HF-induced obesity impairs mitochondria fission and their disposal by mitophagy, which can be in part mitigated by AC intake.
body_text.section: Italy

body_text.text: Rett Syndrome (RTT) is a rare neurodevelopmental disorder caused in the 90% of cases by mutations in the X-linked MECP2 gene, affecting almost exclusively females. Since oxidative stress (OxS) seems to play a key role in the pathogenic mechanism of RTT and the main cellular source of OxS is represented by mitochondria, the aim of our study was to better clarify the functional status of mitochondria in fibroblasts isolated from RTT patients, focusing on morphology, apoptosis and mitophagy. Transmission electron microscopy analysis and Mitotracker staining revealed an altered mitochondrial morphology in RTT fibroblasts. They were characterized by dumbbell-like shape mitochondria, a structural swollen cristae disarrangement in addition to a filamentous interconnected network of elongated and hyperfused mitochondria with an increase in the volume, possibly due to the reduction of the mitochondrial fission factor FIS-1. Interestingly, challenging the cells with the mitochondrial uncouplers 2,4-DNP and FCCP showed an aberrant apoptosis next to an impairment in the mitophagic pathway PINK1/ Parkin-dependent in RTT fibroblasts. Therefore, aberrant accumulation of dysfunctional and hyperfused RTT mitochondria could be detrimental to cellular homeostasis, possibly contributing to the vicious cycle of OxInflammation already proposed for this devastating disease.
body_text.section: Altered mitochondrial morphology, aberrant apoptosis and impaired mitophagy as possible key players in RTT syndrome pathogenesis

body_text.text: Marina A. Darenskaya, Elena V. Genich, Lyudmila A. Several studies have attributed oxidants as critical role players in the genesis of HIV-infection. Data of 50 women of reproductive age with HIV-infection analyzed: women with HIV-infection without (n¼27) and with reproductive disorders (n¼23). Serum and hemolysate used as material for the study. Lipid peroxidation and antioxidant defense (LPO-AOD) parameters were determined by spectrophotometric and fluorometric methods. Average value of initial LPO products -diene conjugates was significantly (1.4 times; p¼0.03) and secondary products -ketodienes and conjugated trienes (2.4 times; p¼0.0002) increased in the group with HIV-infection and reproductive disorders compared to group without disorders. At the same time TBA-active products content showed no significant changes (p>0.05). Decrease in activity of the main antioxidant enzymesuperoxide dismutase (1.19 times; p¼0.01), the levels of α-tocopherol (1.29times) and retinol (1.8-times) was detected in the group with HIVinfection and reproductive disorders compared to the patients without reproductive disorders. Increased levels of oxidized form of glutathione (1.3 times; p¼0.03) in this group were registered also. In women with HIV-infection and reproductive disorders, the oxidative stress and deficiency of antioxidant components were significantly higher than in women without disorders. Suggested to include antioxidant supplements in the complex pathogenetic therapy in these women.
body_text.section: Lipid peroxidation status in women with HIV-infection and reproductive disorders

body_text.text: 44. Ethnic aspects of lipid peroxidation processes in teenagers with obesity and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease Clinical studies indicate an increase in the incidence of obesity in teenagers, hence the issue on studying non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), being a frequent concomitant disease in obesity, is highly relevant. 18 Mongoloid and 17 Caucasian teenagers-boys with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) affected by exogenous constitutional obesity of the first degree have been examined. Data of 37 healthy Mongoloid and 23 Caucasians teenagers-boys for comparison was used. Spectrophotometric and fluorometric methods were used. Mongoloid group with obesity and NAFLD characterized by increased content of lipid peroxidation productsconjugated dienes, ketodienes and conjugated trienes accompanied with increased values of total antioxidant activity, superoxide dismutase activity and reduced levels of α-tocopherol and retinol compared with the control group. In the Caucasian group, statistically significant increased values of ketodienes and conjugated trienes, decreased levels of α-tocopherol, oxidized glutathione and superoxide dismutase activity compared to the control group were noted. Higher value of superoxide dismutase activity in Mongoloids compared to Caucasians ethnic groups with obesity and NAFLD registered. The results allow inclusion of antioxidant drugs in treatment of patients with NAFLD.
body_text.section: Lipid peroxidation status in women with HIV-infection and reproductive disorders

body_text.text: We studied the content of advanced oxidation protein products (AOPP) and carbonyl derivatives (CD) in patients' neutrophils with nephropathy caused by acute alcohol poisoning (AAP) (n¼47). We used healthy donors (n¼35) and patients with AAP without nephropathy (n¼42) as comparison groups. The presence of nephropathy was confirmed by an increase in serum NGAL. Patients' BAC averaged 2.2‰. The age of all individuals ranged from 20-40 years. The GAGE questionnaire was used to confirm AAP and exclude chronic intoxication. We found a significant increase in AOPP level in both with nephropathy and without it (p<0.05) relative to the healthy donors. AOPP level in the group with nephropathy was much higher than in the group without nephropathy (p¼0.006). ANOVA test did not confirm the effect of alcohol poisoning severity on AOPP level. eGFR values influenced the AOPP level. Alcohol poisoning severity was a factor affecting the CD level (F¼12.93, p¼0.0006), while the presence of nephropathy had no effect. So CD level was significantly decreased in moderate severity. There was a negative correlation between AOPP and CD (r¼-0.32), as well as a positive correlation between CD and BAC (r¼0.31). Thus, AOPP can be considered as a predictor of the nephropathy presence. Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is the most common chronic liver disease that ranges from benign steatosis to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). Disturbed hepatic lipid homeostasis, oxygenated cholesterol products (oxysterols) and apoptotic activity is shown to lead the NAFLD development.

body_text.text: Cândida Dias 1,2 , C atia F. Lourenço 1,2 , Rui M. Barbosa 1,2 , Ana Ledo 1,2 , João Laranjinha The reduction of nitrite has recently emerged as an alternative pathway for nitric oxide ( NO) production in vivo. This source of NO may be particularly relevant under conditions of insufficient oxygen supply, which reduces enzymatic production of NO. In fact, nitrite has been shown to be protective in ischemia/reperfusion and appears to be beneficial in aging and neurodegeneration. Importantly, nitrite concentration in vivo can be modulated through the ingestion of nitrate-rich foods. One putative target for the protective activity of nitrite in ischemia is through the modulation of mitochondrial respiration. Here we used highresolution respirometry to determine the effects of nitrite on brain tissue respiration using an in vitro model of ischemia/reperfusion. Thus far we have observed that the oxidative burst observed upon reoxygenation can be abolished by nitrite (10 μM). This inhibition may prevent the increased production of reactive oxygen species associated with the oxidative burst and may explain nitrite's protection during brain ischemia. Future work will focus on confirming whether this effect requires nitrite reduction to NO, as well as determining the site of action of nitrite/ NO within the mitochondrial respiratory chain. Funding: FEDER through COMPETE and FCT -POCI-01-0145-FEDER-007440 and POCI-01-0145-FEDER-029099.
body_text.section: Nitrite modulates mitochondrial respiration in brain ischemia/reperfusion

body_text.text: Periodontitis is prevalent in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD). A chronic state of systemic inflammation is reported in both diseases and associates with poor vascular outcomes. Defining the mechanistic pathways that lead to these poor outcomes may allow stratification of patients for intervention and lead to identification of new therapeutic targets. We hypothesised that oxidation products within the circulation may contribute to poor outcomes and serve as markers of disease comorbidity. We analysed plasma samples from a cohort of 500 CKD patients who fulfilled NICE CKD guidelines for secondary care follow-up for CKD and enrolled in the Renal Impairment in Secondary Care (RIISC) study. Periodontal health was assessed as bleeding on probing and clinical attachment loss. Plasma samples were analysed for protein carbonyls and F2-α-isoprostanes using ELISA methods. Multiple regression analysis showed that plasma protein carbonyls were significantly negatively correlated with estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR; P<0.001), and with periodontal disease; clinical attachment loss (P¼0.046). Plasma F2-α-isoprostanes were significantly and negatively correlated with eGFR (P¼0.031) and bleeding on probing (P¼0.074). This data suggests that oxidation in the circulating proteome and lipidome increases with increasing CKD severity and provide a possible mechanism for increased co-morbidity with periodontitis.

body_text.text: The enrichment of flaxseed oil, which is a valuable vegetable source of PUFA omega-3, fat-soluble vitamins and other biologically active substances (BAS), makes it possible to strengthen the therapeutic and prophylactic effect of flaxseed oil. Experiments were conducted to investigate the influence of added BAS (coenzyme Q10, β-carotene, lutein, zeaxanthin, α-tocopherol, α-tocopherol acetate, cholecalciferol, selenomethionine) on the oxidative stability of flaxseed oil. It has been shown that the BAS additives can significantly (р < 0.05) change the rate of accumulation of primary and secondary oxidation products, free fatty acids in flaxseed oil thus exhibiting both antioxidant and pro-oxidant properties. The actual result depends on the nature of the additive and its concentration in the oil. The fat-soluble esters of ascorbic acid and their compositions with natural antioxidants based on bean and soybeans appeared to be effective and safe stabilizers of flaxseed oil enriched with BAS, thus increasing shelf life, improving the effectiveness of products based on enriched flaxseed oil. Based on the research results, new, oxidation-resistant functional food products based on flaxseed oil have been developed. Their use by humans could improve the diet and contribute to the prevention and treatment of a wide range of diseases.

body_text.text: 51. Characterization of amyloid precursor protein processing and oxidative stress in iPSC-derived neuron and astrocyte co-cultures carrying a PSEN1 mutation (Hill et al., 2016) . Using this approach, we cultured cortical networks that carry a mutation in the presenillin-1 (PSEN1) gene and compared markers associated with altered amyloid precursor protein processing and oxidative stress. Materials and methods: Human iPSCderived neural precursors cells (ax0018, ax0112, Axol Biosciences) were cultured for 40 days into neuron and astrocyte co-cultures. Immunocytochemical staining was used to identify cellular localisation of TUJ-1, S100b, ADAM10 and APP. ADAM10 and APPr expression was measured via western blotting. Protein carbonyls, lipid peroxidation, DNA damage and antioxidant capacity were also assessed as markers of oxidative stress. Results: ADAM10 expression and APPr was significantly reduced in iPSC co-cultures carrying the PSEN1 mutation (p<0.05) compared to control. Protein carbonyls, lipid peroxidation, F2isoprostanes and DNA oxidation was significantly elevated in PSEN1 cells (p<0.05). Conclusions: iPSC derived cortical networks carrying a PSEN1 mutation have a decreased ratio of APP isoforms (130kDa:110kDa) and increased markers of oxidative stress compared healthy control cells. Telomeres are ribonucleoprotein complexes that cap and protect chromosome ends. Human telomeric DNA naturally shortens during somatic cell division and also as a result of oxidative damage. Telomere erosion eventually compromises telomere integrity, triggering a DNA damage response which results in the onset of cellular senescence. The loss of telomere integrity and the accumulation of senescent cells with ageing have been increasingly implicated in the loss of tissue homeostasis and the development of age-related pathologies. Hence understanding the factors and mechanisms that control these processes may be relevant to develop strategies for heathier ageing. In this presentation I will review evidence linking telomere length with environmental, psychosocial and life-style factors. I will also discuss the association between accelerated telomere shortening, psychological stress, stress responsiveness and the possible role of oxidative stress as a mediating mechanism. Finally, I will examine potential non-pharmacological interventions that might counteract telomere damage, thus promoting genomic stability and cell longevity.

body_text.text: 53. Peroxyl radicals induce oxidative crosslinking of superoxide dismutase 1 through self-reaction of protein radicals Introduction: Oxidation of proteins can generate protein crosslinks through self-reaction of protein-derived radicals, with the yields dependent on the steady state concentration of the initial oxidant. Hypothesis: Peroxyl radicals (ROO ) produced by thermolysis of AAPH (2,2 0 -azobis(2-methylpropionamidine)dihydrochloride) would mediate oxidation of Trp and Tyr residues in human and bovine superoxide dismutase-1 (SOD1), respectively, leading to Trp-Trp and Tyr-Tyr crosslinks. Experimental: SOD1 (3 mg/mL) were incubated with AAPH (10-100 mM) in phosphate buffer (37 C). Samples were analysed by SDS-PAGE, amino acid analysis, carbonyl quantification, and enzymatic activity (cytochrome c assay). Cross-links were detected in hydrolysed proteins by mass spectrometry. Results: AAPH-mediated oxidation (3 h) generated protein dimers. With 100 mM AAPH, this was accompanied by consumption of parent Trp for human-SOD1, and limited losses of parent Tyr in bovine-SOD1. Trp-Trp (m/z ¼ 407) and Tyr-Tyr (m/z ¼ 361) crosslinks were detected in oxidized and hydrolysed human-SOD1 and bovine-SOD1 samples respectively. Carbonyl yields increased in a linear manner over time, implying limited production of carbonyl-dependent, Schiffbase-derived crosslinks. Conclusions: Low rates of ROO production induce SOD1 crosslinking via Tyr-Tyr and Trp-Trp bonds.

body_text.text: A nanoparticulate gel has been designed for wound healing treatment. Namely the vehicle has been specifically formulated to apply on the skin both hyaluronic acid and the antioxidant retinyl palmitate. The latter has been loaded in lipid nanoparticles suitable to solubilize this lipophilic molecule. Particularly retinyl palmitate has been encapsulated both in solid lipid nanoparticles and nanostructured lipid carriers, respectively constituted of pure tristearin or a mixture of tristearin and caprylic/ capric triglyceride. Nanoparticles were characterized by discoidal and flat shape, lamellar inner structure, as evidenced by cryogenic transmission electron microscopy and x-ray, while their mean diameter was 132 nm, as measured by photon correlation spectroscopy. The presence of the liquid caprylic/capric triglyceride within nanostructured lipid carriers allowed to encapsulate retinyl palmitate more efficiently with respect to solid lipid nanoparticles. In order to obtain a gel to be applied on the wounds, hyaluronic acid has been directly added into the aqueous dispersion of nanostructured lipid carriers containing retinyl palmitate. The nanoparticulate gel "wound healing" effect has been evaluated in scratch wound assay in keratinocytes. The wounded areas of treated and control cells displayed significant differences during the first 24 h postwounding, indicating a synergic effect of retinyl palmitate and hyaluronic acid. Although neutrophil granulocytes are usually regarded as archetypical pro-inflammatory cells, they also can exert anti-inflammatory and immunoregulatory functions. In previous studies, we showed that reactive oxygen species (ROS)-dependent formation of aggregated neutrophil extracellular traps (aggNETs) is crucial for resolution of inflammation of experimental arthritis and lupus. The underlying mechanism involves neutrophil serine proteases that degrade locally released cytokines and chemokines and thereby interrupt ongoing inflammatory processes. In this project we aimed to employ restoration and amplification of NET formation for inducing resolution of innate-and autoimmune-driven inflammation. To this end we made use of NADPH oxidase (NOX) 2-activating sulfonamides and aminoferrocene-based NOX2-independent ROS amplifiers. Preliminary data suggest that the NOX2-activator RE-02 induces (agg)NET formation and alleviates experimental lupus and that the aminoferrocene-based prodrug MIS43 triggeres (agg)NET formation and prevents chronification of gouty arthritis in mice with non-functional NOX2. Treatment with MIS43 was associated with lower local levels of inflammatory cytokines/chemokines. Taken together, the studies suggest a therapeutic efficiency of ROS-induction in chronic inflammatory syndromes that occur in the context of defective NOX2. The mechanism of OH-induced oxidation of γ-Glu-(Pro) n -Met peptides (n ¼ 0 -3) was investigated in aqueous solutions using pulse radiolysis techniques. Using such peptides allowed for distance control between the side-chain sulfur of Met and the amino group of Glu. Interactions between them were probed by monitoring formation of C-centered, Rutin has been shown to be beneficial to aquatic organisms, since it improves their immune, anti-inflammatory and antioxidant responses. However, it is unknown how rutin acts in response to a challenging situation as Aeromonas hydrophila infection in silver catfish. The aims of this research were to assess the influence of the dietary supplementation with rutin on inflammation and antioxidant responses in muscle of silver catfish challenged with A. hydrophila. Fish were split into four groups as follows (in triplicate, n ¼ 12): control, 0.15% rutin, A. hydrophila, 0.15% rutin þ A. hydrophila. After 2 weeks of feeding with standard or rutin diets, fish were challenged with A. hydrophila for 1 week. The animals were then anesthetized with eugenol and euthanized to collect muscle. Dietary supplementation with rutin reduced A. hydrophila inducedhaemorrhage and inflammatory infiltrate in muscle of silver catfish. Although it was not able to recover the levels of reduced glutathione (GSH), cysteine and glutamate cysteine ligase levels, it diminished the oxidized glutathione (GSSG) contents, thus decreasing GSSG to GSH ratio in muscle of silver catfish. Finally, such treatment reduced A. hydrophila induced-lipid peroxidation and markedly elevates ascorbic acid levels, re-establishing total antioxidant capacity in muscle of silver catfish. Redox disturbance and subsequent oxidative stress have been linked to the pathophysiology of first-episode psychosis (FEP). Coupled with depletion in glutathione (GSH), the primary antioxidant in the brain, FEP provides an early-intervention point for treatment. Exercise training can perturb oxidative stress and rebalance the antioxidant system in healthy participants, with potential to benefit an FEP population. The aim of this study was to explore oxidative stress as a mechanism by which exercise offers protection. 22 young men were recruited from Birmingham Early Intervention services and randomized to a 12-week exercise programme, or treatment as usual. Measures of GSH, markers of oxidative damage, inflammation, symptomology and lifestyle changes were assessed. Exercise had a positive effect on measures of protein damage, inflammation, symptom score and a self-assessment of disability. For markers of neurocognition, lipid damage and antioxidant ability, exercise attenuated negative effects observed in the non-exercising control group. Peripheral GSH was increased in the exercise group by 5.6%, and control group GSH was significantly depleted (P¼0.04). Exercise training was affected by cannabis consumption, antipsychotic medication and BMI. Moderate intensity exercise training has the ability to elicit clinically important changes in oxidative damage and antioxidant concentration, with subsequent improvements in symptoms of psychosis. Myeloperoxidase (MPO) is released by activated immune cells and forms the oxidants hypochlorous acid (HOCl) and hypothiocyanous acid (HOSCN). MPO and overproduction of HOCl are strongly linked with vascular cell dysfunction and inflammation in atherosclerosis. HOSCN is less damaging, reacting in a selective and reversible manner with thiols, leading to the hypothesis that thiocyanate (SCN -) may be protective during chronic inflammation. This project examines the reactivity of HOCl and HOSCN with vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMC), and the ability of SCNto influence HOCl-induced damage. Exposure of human coronary artery smooth muscle cells (HCASMC) to HOCl and HOSCN decreased viability and induced altered intracellular calcium and apoptotic cell death. This was more extensive with HOCl and could be prevented by addition of SCN -. Both oxidants significantly decreased cellular thiols, but the oxidation was reversible to some extent in each case. HOCl and HOSCN differentially altered the expression of genes associated with oxidative stress and inflammation, with the changes seen with HOCl influenced by the presence of SCN -. Together, these data are consistent with SCNconsuming HOCl, to form HOSCN, which is less damaging to VSMC. This may have potential therapeutic implications for atherosclerosis. In the last years, several metallocifen compounds have been identified as promising anticancer drugs (1). We present here the comparison of some biological effects of two complexes of this family, 1 and 2, which differ only by the position of the metallocene (ferrocenyl) unit on the carbons of the double bond but show very different antiproliferative activity on breast cancer cells. Actually, while complex 1 exhibits a strong antiproliferative activity on breast cancer cells, 2 is by far less cytotoxic. In MDA-MB-231 cells, we found that complex 1, but not 2, was able (1) to increase lipid peroxidation (2) to decrease the mitochondrial membrane potential (3) to induce redox imbalance. In vitro, 1 and 2 significantly inhibited thioredoxin reductase after their enzymatic oxidation. Cellular amount of iron, quantified by ICP-OES was significantly higher after incubation with 1 than with 2. The differences of biological activities underline the essential role played by the ferrocene-ene-phenol motif in trans conjugation presents in 1 but not in 2. The antioxidants role in cell response regulation attracted great interest in the last decades and it is undergoing to a profound reconsideration. The mere concept of "biological antioxidant" has been frequently misconceived or misused, possibly leading to the misinterpretation of some experimental observation. Organosulfur compounds in general and α-lipoic acid, a dithiol molecule, can be considered a typical example of the kind. Reduced αlipoic acid, dehydrolipoic acid has been in fact originally considered a bona fide, reducing, electron donor molecule. A more recent approach, according to stoichiometric and thermodynamic evidences, lead to a reinterpretation of the biochemical role of "antioxidants". The electrophilic nature of oxidized nucleophilic molecules, including α-lipoic acid, renders more plausible a mechanism based on the ability to activate Nrf2/EpRE mediated hormetic response. In this study, we demonstrate that nmolar concentrations of oxidized α-lipoic acid, but not dehydrolipoic acid, protect human umbilical primary endothelial cells (HUVEC) from TNF-α induced dysfunction, inhibit NF-κB activation and block apoptosis following the activation of Nrf2 transcription factor. Our observations corroborate the concept that the major, if not the unique, mechanism by which α-lipoic acid can nonenzymatically exert its reducing activity is related to the electrophilic nature of the oxidized form.

body_text.text: 67. Evolution of antioxidant system: a comparative study on fish models Animals have to manage oxidative stress generated by their own metabolism and evolved detoxifying systems to oppose different oxidative stimulus. Although many studies have been conducted on the antioxidant system of mammalian cells, increasing evidence demonstrates that orthologous systems exist in other vertebrates, such as the zebrafish Danio rerio. Recent works indicate the advantages of zebrafish as useful model to clarify the crosstalk between oxidative mechanisms and inflammatory processes. The aim of this work was to investigate how the environment affects the evolution of defensive and inflammatory system. Specifically, we compared the blind cavefish Phreatichthys andruzzii, a teleost species evolved for 3 million years in extreme hypogean conditions in the phreatic layer of the Somalian desert, with the zebrafish. In paEPA and zfPAC2 cell lines, using Amplex Red assay and the treatment with glucose oxidase, we found a different basal oxidative status and a different response to induced stressful pro-oxidant stimulus between the two models. These results were confirmed by analysis of phase II antioxidant enzymes at gene expression and protein level. The elucidation of mechanisms involved in these processes could provide useful tools to expand our knowledge on the antioxidant-inflammatory pathways involved in pathogenesis of human disease. In our laboratory we evaluated N-Acetylcysteine (NAC) effects by its addition to cell culture media. We demonstrated that NAC inhibits adipogenic differentiation of 3T3-L1 preadipocytes (Soto et al, 2017) . Here, we performed treatments with 0.01 to 5 mM NAC, on 3T3-L1 adipocytes (AC). NAC cellular uptake, in 5mM NAC treated 3T3-L1 adipocytes (ACN-5), was only 17.4% of total NAC added. Highest NAC dose decreased total cholesterol content (Chol) (1.61 AE 0.50 g Chol / g protein [ACN-5] vs 5.73 AE 0.02 g Chol/ g protein [AC], p < 0.05). We evaluated cytotoxicity by colorimetric assay using 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide; none dose of NAC was cytotoxic (OD: 0.85 AE 0.02 [ACN-5] vs 0.81 AE 0.08 [AC] , no significant difference). We developed spherical porous silica nanoparticles (20 AE 4.5 nm), in which we encapsulated 5mM NAC (NPsSiO 2 -NAC), and evaluated their cytotoxicity. Samples of 0.05mg/mL showed 42.3 % cytotoxicity (OD: 0.41AE0.04 [NPsSiO 2 -NAC] vs 0.71AE0.04 [nontoxic control], p < 0.01); with a cover of bovine sera albumin (8nm) we obtained nontoxic NACnanoparticles (OD: 0.91AE0.09 [NPsSiO 2 -NAC] vs 0.90AE0.08 [nontoxic control], no significant difference). NAC release was completed within 28 hours. This tool for NAC delivery could increase NAC cellular uptake and its effect on lipid content.

body_text.text: Mara Gagliardi, Diego Cotella, Claudio Santoro, Davide Cor a, Mauro Piacentini, Marco Corazzari University of Eastern Piedmont, Novara, Italy, and University of Rome "Tor Vergata", Italy Cutaneous melanoma, the most aggressive form of skin cancer, remains one of the most difficult to treat human malignancies. Oncogenic mutations in the RAS/RAF pathway are mostly involved in melanoma, with BRAF V600E present in 40-60% of all melanomas. Notoriously unresponsive and resistant to therapy, metastatic melanoma is highly invasive and evolved molecular defences against immunological and cytotoxic attack. Hence, new and most effective therapies are urgently needed. Recently, a new form of cell death has been described, with iron representing the main actor and lipid-ROS playing a pivotal role, named ferroptosis. This pathway might represent a new valuable approach to treat resistant malignancies, such as human melanoma. We found that most melanoma cell lines are resistant to ferroptosis execution. However, all resistant cells are competent to induce the early stage of this cell death program as described by the early upregulation of the main ferroptotic marker CHAC1, indicating a downstream block of the signalling pathway. In fact, we identified the involvement of aldo-keto reductases (AKR1C1Ä3) as potential detoxifying enzymes responsible for downstream inhibition of ferroptosis execution. We also found that NRF2 plays a key role in both AKRs and CHAC1 gene expression modulation during ferroptosis induction and execution.
body_text.section: Aldo-keto reductases protect melanoma cells from erastininduced er-stress independent ferroptosis

body_text.text: Luke F. Gamon, Michael J. Davies
body_text.section: Absolute quantitative analysis of intact and oxidised amino acids by LCMS without prior derivatization

body_text.text: The precise characterisation and quantification of oxidative protein damage is a significant scientific challenge due to the low abundance, large variety and heterogeneity of oxidative modifications. Current approaches such as mass spectrometry-based proteomic techniques provide a detailed but probably incomplete picture due to incomplete sequence coverage and less-than-ideal enzymatic hydrolysis. This is a particular problem with heavily modified and cross-linked / aggregated proteins. While significant progress has been made, there is still a pressing need for methods that can quantify large numbers of low abundance species in a rapid and reliable fashion. We have developed a novel protocol using zwitterionic ionexchange chromatography coupled with high-resolution mass spectrometry to simultaneously quantify both parent amino acids and their respective oxidation products. Proteins are hydrolysed with methanesulfonic acid in the presence of tryptamine and purified by strong cation exchange solid phase extraction prior to analysis. This method represents a platform for the discovery of novel modifications and allows for simultaneous screening of large numbers of reaction products, both known and novel. The method complements existing targeted proteomic techniques, and allows precise quantification of the mass balance, or yield, of a broad range of oxidative modifications relative to parent materials.

body_text.text: Ombretta Garbarino, Barbara Marengo, Lorenzo Monteleone, Gabriella Pietra, Silvia Ravera, Mario Passalacqua, Santina Bruzzone, and Cinzia Domenicotti
body_text.section: Characterization of metabolic and molecular response of a human melanoma cell line resistant to PLX4032

body_text.text: Melanoma is one of the most aggressive forms of skin cancer, and its extreme heterogeneity limits the efficacy of the treatments, causing high percentage of post-therapy relapses. To better understand the molecular mechanisms of therapy resistance, a BRAF-mutated melanoma cell line was isolated from a patient biopsy and long-term exposed to increasing concentrations of Vemurafenib (PLX4032). Despite the resistance, the acute treatment with PLX of PLX-Resistant cells partially reduced the MAPKinase activity, suggesting that other signalling pathways are involved in chemoresistance. PLX-Resistant cells maintained an efficient oxidative phosphorylation and a reticulate organization of mitochondria up to 72 hrs treatment, while DMSO-Resistant cells acutely-treated with PLX showed a shift to glycolytic pathway and loss of mitochondrial reticulate organization. However, these metabolic alterations were not accompanied by changes in reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in both PLX-Resistant and DMSO-Resistant cell populations. Collectively, our data demonstrate that the acquired PLX-resistance confers to melanoma cells the ability to preserve the mitochondrial efficiency, suggesting that mitochondrial respiration should have a prosurvival role that limits the efficacy of the treatment. Further studies are needed to better understand the molecular mechanisms underlying PLX4032 resistance of BRAF-mutated melanoma cells (Grants from Genoa University). The development of silver nanoparticles (AgNP) applications increased the concern about their toxicity. As the respiratory system in one of the exposure routes, the aim of this study was to evaluate the AgNP harmful effects developed in lung. AgNP were able to cleave H 2 O 2 leading to OH production. In A549 cells exposed to 2.5 μg/mL AgNP a decreased mitochondrial basal and maximal respiration (p<0.01) were observed after 3h, while an increased H 2 O 2 production was observed after 1h (p<0.001), which in turn, increased the 4-HNE (p<0.01) and HO-1 (p<0.01) levels after 24h. In an EpiAirway 3D tissue AgNP exposure decreased the transepithelial electrical resistance (p<0.05). In vivo AgNP effects were evaluated using Balb/c mice instilled with 0.1 mg AgNP/kg body weight. Biodistribution evaluation showed the lung as the main organ of AgNP deposition, where 1h after AgNP exposure tissue O2 consumption increased (p<0.05) due to increased NOX activity (p<0.05) and increased mitochondrial respiration (p<0.001) mainly by increased complex I activity (p<0.01). Mitochondrial H 2 O 2 production rate increased (p<0.05) along with increased antioxidant enzymes activity (p<0.01) and decreased GSH/GSSG ratio. These results show that AgNP presence in the lung may lead to oxidative damage and impaired epithelial function due to O 2 metabolism alterations.

body_text.section: Alterations in response to Resistin induced oxidative stress in circulating leukocytes from patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)

body_text.text: We previously demonstrated that Resistin (RES) decrease reactive oxygen species levels (ROS) in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) in non-NAFLD, but not in NAFLD patients. To further evaluate RES effects on oxidative stress and on antioxidant defenses (Aox) in PBMC from NAFLD patients, PBMC were cultured in presence/absence of RES (20 ng/ml) for 24h. PBMC from NAFLD patients had higher baseline ROS levels (1353 AE 498 vs. 468 AE 89, vs. non-NAFLD cells). In addition, PBMC from NAFLD patients showed lower superoxide dismutase (SOD) and glutathione reductase (GRd) activities, and higher glutathione peroxidase activity (p <0.05) than non-NAFLD PBMC. 24h incubation with RES induced an increase in catalase and GRd activities (p<0.01), and a decrease in SOD activity (p< 0.05) and glutathione content (p<0.05) in non-NAFLD PBMC. However, RES could not modulate enzymatic activities in PBMC from NALFD patients. In conclusion, RES presence favored the decrease in ROS in non-NAFLD PBMC by modulating Aox enzymes and GSH redox state, but not in PBMC from NAFLD patients. Redox signaling alterations would favor the inflammatory state and the progression of NALFD. The regulatory mechanisms controlled by Res could be used as potential therapeutic targets in NAFLD patients. Support:

body_text.text: Renato Simões Gaspar, Plinio Minghin Freitas Ferreira, Jonathan Gibbins University of Reading, UK Background: NADPH oxidases (Nox) and protein disulphide isomerase (PDI) have been shown to modulate reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in endothelial cells and leukocytes. In platelets, both Nox and PDI individually contribute to platelet activation. Understanding how platelets generate ROS and how Nox and PDI interact might provide better tools to treat and prevent thrombotic events. Methods: Human washed platelets and platelet-derived extracellular vesicles (PDEV) were used. ROS were quantified using DCF and DHE dyes. Reductase activity was measured in whole platelets using the fluorescent substrate Di-E-GssG. Platelet function was evaluated through aggregometry and protein expression determined by immunoblotting. Results: PDI and Nox-1 inhibitors decreased platelet ROS production. Curiously, Nox inhibition increased platelet reductase activity while PDI and Nox-1 inhibitors synergized to reduce platelet aggregation. Various components of the Nox pathway were identified in PDEVs for the first time, which were shown to produce ROS in a Nox-1-dependent way. Importantly, Nox-1 and 2 were found to be enriched in PDEVs after platelet activation. Conclusion: Nox-1 and PDI are intrinsic enzymatic systems that synergize to modulate platelet aggregation. The enrichment of Nox-1 on PDEVs and its impact on ROS production suggest PDEVs could interact with other platelets through redox signalling.

Flavonoids have been shown to inhibit platelet activation through diverse mechanisms, such as the inhibition of protein disulphide isomerase (PDI), the leading member of platelet thiol isomerases. In the present study, we investigated the potential anti-platelet properties of the flavonoid myricetin. The effects of myricetin (7.5, 15 and 30 μM) on platelet function were assessed through platelet aggregation, activation, secretion and spreading assays. Reductase activity of platelet thiol isomerases ERp5, ERp57, ERp72 and PDI, was also measured in the absence or presence of myricetin (0.01-10 μM). The interaction between myricetin and the abovementioned thiol isomerases was evaluated through molecular docking. Myricetin dose-dependently inhibited platelet aggregation, fibrinogen binding and alpha granule exposure induced by various agonists of the collagen and thrombin pathways.
body_text.section: Myricetin inhibits platelet function via thiol isomerases inhibition

body_text.text: Interestingly, myricetin (30 μM) inhibited platelet spreading to collagen in nearly 25%. In silico studies suggested myricetin formed non-covalent bonds with all thiol isomerases studied. Despite the predicted interaction, this flavonoid inhibited the reductase activity of PDI and ERp5 (IC50~3.5 μM), but not ERp57 and ERp72. In conclusion, data herein presented identified myricetin as a potent novel antiplatelet compound that strongly inhibits thiol isomerases on platelets.

Proteomic analysis of cannabidiol effect on human skin fibroblasts exposed to UVA or UVB irradiation Cannabidiol, as a natural non-psychoactive cannabinoid, is considered as a very promising compound in the treatment of various diseases connected with chronic inflammation including skin disorders. Therefore, the aim of this study was to examine the cannabidiol effect on UVA and UVB-induced changes in proteome profile of human skin fibroblasts cultured in vitro. PCA analysis of results obtained by QExactive OrbiTrap mass spectrometer show clear differentiation between UVA/B-irradiated cells and cells treated with cannabidiol following UV radiation. The main differences are observed in the case of proteins involved in inflammation and apoptosiscannabidiol significantly reduces the UV-induced expression of proinflammatory (e.g. NFκB, IL-17) and proapoptotic (e.g. p53 and cytochrome c) factors. Moreover, cannabidiol added to UVA/B irradiated cells also significantly decreases the level of Advanced Glycation Endproducts (AGEs, by about 45% and 50%, respectively) including cysteine and lysine carboxymethylation/carboxyethylation, what is observed mainly in the case of the proteins with transporter and catalytic activity.

body_text.text: Our group recently observed that protein S-glutathionylation plays a vital role in controlling mitochondrial bioenergetics in the muscles of male mice. Mice deficient in glutaredoxin-2 (GRX2), the enzyme that drives glutathionylation, were resistant to diet-induced obesity (DIO) and the development of related disorders (e.g. fatty liver). This effect was associated with increased proton leaks through uncoupling protein-3 activity and fuel combustion in muscles. Based on this, we investigated if the same phenotype exists in female GRX2-deficient mice challenged with a high-fat diet. Unlike male mice, female WT littermates were completely resistant to developing DIO and related co-morbidities. Additionally, deleting the Grx2 gene did not alter the weight gain profiles and adiposity in these mice. Furthermore, while differences in reactive oxygen species generation in liver mitochondria were observed, this trend is not present in muscle mitochondria. Measurement of mitochondrial bioenergetics also revealed no differences in fuel combustion or respiration in WT and GRX2-deficient mice fed a control or high-fat diet. Taken together, we show for the first time that a sexual dimorphism exists for mitochondrial redox signalling through the GRX2 pathway.

The functional and structural integrity of the brain rely on a prompt delivery of metabolic substrates (via local changes in cerebral blood flow) matching the increase in neuronal activity. The dysfunction of this process -neurovascular coupling (NVC)is suggested to critically contribute to neurodegeneration. Considering that neuronal-derived nitric oxide ( • NO) is a direct mediator of NVC in the hippocampus, it is hypothesized that modulation of circulating nitrite levels (via dietary intervention) may convey a pathway to sustain NVC under hypoxic conditions. To test this hypothesis in vitro studies were carried out to address the reduction of nitrite in acidic medium. In particular, chemiluminescence and electrochemical approaches were used to explore the production of • NO via nitrite reduction in the presence of several physiological reductants (eg. ascorbate, zinc, etc.). Parallel in vivo studies were designed to validate the hypothesis in a rodent model of vascular dementia, encompassing the evaluation of the functional impact of acute nitrate/ ascorbate administration in the neurovascular coupling.

body_text.text: Results support nitrite-to-• NO reduction by ascorbate in a pH dependent Cellular senescence is a strictly regulated mechanism that can be divided into two categories: the replicative and the stress induced senescence. Stress can be caused by a variety of factors, such as the reactive oxygen species. The Growth Arrest and DNA Damage Gadd45a protein is involved in pathways that respond to various stressors, but its connection with oxidative stress (OS) remains elusive. Here, we study the function of Gadd45 in young and old mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) subjected to 300μМ H 2 O 2 for 30min and left to recover for different lengths of time. mRNA and protein levels of Gadd45 were calculated using RT-qPCR and western blot analysis, respectively. Number of centrosomes, mitotic defects and DNA damage levels were also assessed. Our results showed that in young MSCs, levels of Gadd45 increased for 1 hour after OS and return to basal levels after 24 hours. Old MSCs had significantly lower levels of Gadd45a and failed to adjust them in response to OS. These defects were accompanied with centrosome amplification, mitotic defects and an attenuation of DNA damage repair ability. In conclusion, our results implicate Gadd45a in OS response and suggest a role for this molecule in the development of senescence features. body_text.text: Objectives: This study was planned to understand whether total antioxidant status (TAS), total oxidant status (TOS) and oxidative stress index (OSI) can be used as a determination factor for the severity of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and prediabetes. Methods: Among 69 women who were recruited to our study, 19 were first time diagnosed as type 2 diabetic, 24 were first time diagnosed as prediabetic and 26 were found healthy. Blood samples were collected at the time of their arrival to our hospital to calculate OSI after the measurement of TOS and TAS. Results: No significant difference was found in TAS values. However, TOS values were significantly higher in type 2 diabetics than prediabetics (p<0.001) and controls (p<0.005). OSI values were significantly higher in type 2 diabetics than prediabetics and controls (p<0.001 and p<0.05). Conclusion: Our findings of an increase in serum oxidant levels and OSI values in T2DM may contribute to further studies investigating the physiopathology of diabetes mellitus. Reactive oxygen species (ROS) homeostasis and dynamic intracellular reductive/oxidative (redox) balance play a key role in regulating cell survival/death. One of the significant features of cancer cells, when compared to the normal ones, is a persistent pro-oxidative state. In cancer cells, the events such as activation of oncogenes, aberrant metabolism, and mitochondrial dysfunction can increase ROS levels, leading to intrinsic oxidative stress. Therefore, malignant cells would be more dependent on antioxidants for cell survival and more vulnerable to further oxidative insults than their normal counterparts. This is the biological basis of redox-based anticancer strategy. In the current study, we have found that auranofin, a promising anticancer drug and known thioredoxin reductase inhibitor, induces cancer cell death through redoxmediated mechanisms affecting both thioredoxin and glutathione systems. Interestingly, cellular sensitivity to auranofin depends on intracellular antioxidant capacity. We have further identified that combinations of auranofin with several other anticancer molecules that increase ROS generation and/or affect redox homeostasis display synergistic anticancer activity both in cell culture and in mouse xenografted with breast cancer cell lines. Our data provide mechanistic insight and preclinical evidence that redox modulation and enhanced generation of oxidative stress could be an alternative anticancer strategy. Oxidative stress triggers the formation of lipid droplets (LDs) in the liver by stimulating lipogenesis and simultaneously suppresses lipoprotein secretion. Here we report that fasting causes an aberrant accumulation of LDs associated with systemic organ disorders in SOD1-knockout (KO) mice. After three days of fasting, approximately half of the KO mice were starved to death and could not be recovered by feeding, whereas wildtype (WT) mice were totally survived. The fasting also triggered organ failure such as increased rate of hydronephrosis and aberrant cardiac function in KO mice. Furthermore, LDs had accumulated and retained in KO mouse organs that routinely catalyze fatty acids via β-oxidation, although the levels of free fatty acids and ketone bodies in plasma were less in KO mice compared to WT mice during the period of fasting. Feeding a high calorie-diet for two weeks prior to fasting effectively mitigated its organ failure in the KO mice, despite the enhanced accumulation of LDs. These collective data suggest that the lipid-catabolizing system is the sensitive target of oxidative stress triggered by fasting conditions in the KO mice.

body_text.text: 85. Oxysterols and TLR-mediated intestinal inflammation: protective effect of cocoa bean shells. a smart way for waste valorisation Noemi Iaia, Daniela Rossin, Letricia Barbosa-Perreira, Giuseppe Poli, Giuseppe Zeppa, Fiorella Biasi.

Dietary oxysterols' ability to induce intestinal inflammation is widely known. Considering the important role of Toll-like receptors (TLRs) in mediating immune and inflammatory responses, we verified if a mixture of oxysterols widely present in cholesterol-rich foods could require TLR2 and TLR4 activation to promote intestinal inflammation. Furthermore, the protective effects of cocoa bean shell (CBS) extracts with high polyphenolic content were also investigated. Differentiated CaCo-2 enterocyte-like cells were treated with a dietary oxysterol mixture and TLR2/4 gene expression and activation were analysed. Inflammation was evaluated by quantifying IL-8, IFNβ and TNFα cell release. Honduras CBS polyphenolic fractions (HFs) were characterized by HPLC-DAD-MS/MS. The HF anti-inflammatory effects were evaluated in cells under oxysterol mixture treatment. We observed that TLR2 and TLR4 activation is required to mediate oxysterol pro-inflammatory effects. HF pre-treatments fully prevented the oxysterol-dependent cytokine induction, as well as TLR2/4 overexpression. These effects may be due to the high (-)-epicatechin and tannin quantities present in specific HFs. In conclusion, TLR2 and TLR4 can definitely contribute to mediate oxysterol pro-inflammatory action on intestinal cells. CBS fractions could be employed as anti-inflammatory food supplements, thus representing an important industrial design for recycling.

Ellagic acid protects the intestinal barrier against inflammation/oxidative stress induced permeabilization Dario E. Iglesias 1,2,3 , Cesar G. Fraga 1,2,3 , and Patricia I. Oteiza 1, 4 Department of Nutrition, University of California, Davis, CA, USA 2 Physical Chemistry, School of Pharmacy and Biochemistry, University of Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, Argentina IBIMOL, University of Buenos Aires-CONICET, School of Pharmacy and Biochemistry, University of Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, Argentina 4 Department of Environmental Toxicology, University of California, Davis, CA, USA Chronic intestinal inflammation involves a cycle of oxidative stress, NF-κB activation, and barrier permeabilization. The latter can lead to systemic inflammation and associated co morbidities. Diet is crucial in modulating intestinal inflammation. Among plant bioactives, ellagic acid (EA) was reported to inhibit inflammatory bowel disease in animal models. This work investigated EA capacity to inhibit tumor necrosis alpha (TNFα) induced inflammation, oxidative stress, and myosin light chain kinase (MLCK) regulated loss of barrier integrity. Caco-2 cells differentiated into an intestinal epithelial cell monolayer were incubated with TNFα (10 ng/ml), in the presence of different EA concentrations. TNFα triggered interleukin 6 and 8 release into the medium, which was inhibited by EA in a dose-dependent manner (IC50¼17.3 μM for interleukin-6). TNFα also led to: i) increased NOX1 expression; ii) decreased mitochondrial membrane potential; iii) increased oxidant production; iv) NF-κB activation; v) MLCK upregulation; and vi) monolayer permeabilization. EA (10-40 μM) inhibited all these adverse effects of TNFα. EA mainly acts through NF-κB inhibition breaking the cycle of oxidative stress, NF κB activation, and intestinal permeabilization. This suggests the consumption of EA, via foods or supplements may afford a strategy to mitigate intestinal inflammation and associated comorbidities. body_text.text: Thyroid disorders caused by a deficiency of iodide in human and animal diets are a growing concern in the world. International health organizations such as the WHO promote the addition of iodide to food products (e.g. as sodium iodide) and the consumption of food naturally rich in this element. Iodide (Iˉ) is an important substrate used in the biosynthesis of thyroid hormones, thyroxine and triiodothyronine by thyroid peroxidase 1 , via reactions which involve iodide oxidation. Liver necrosis caused by agents such as thioacetamide (TAA) has been linked to alterations in the redox-state; on the other hand, it is well known that Gadolinium chloride (GD) attenuates drug-induced hepatotoxicity by selectively inactivating of Kupffer cells (KC). In the present work, this inactivation was studied in reference to antioxidant defense system on TAA necrosis model. Two months male rats, intravenously pretreated with a single dose of GD (0.1 mmol/Kg), were intraperitoneally injected with TAA (6.6 mmol/Kg). Samples of blood and liver were obtained from rats at 0, 12, 24, 48, 72 and 96 h following TAA in order to evaluate the mechanisms in the post-necrotic state. Activity and expression of superoxide dismutase Cu-Zn (CuZnSOD) and Mn (MnSOD), catalase (CAT), glutathione peroxidase (GPX) and glutathione reductase (GR) was measured. In our results, both GR and GPx were induced 24h after TAA, and the pretreatment with GD significantly reduced this induction, showing a profile similar to control. GD did not produce alterations in the profile of CAT, CuZnSOD and MnSOD. Futher studies are necessary to known the mechanism, but the modulation of KC function may serve as a potential target for therapeutics and could prevent oxidative damage induced by drugs.
