body_text.text: Saowanee Jeayeng, Somponnat Sampattavanich, Uraiwan Panich Department of Pharmacology, Faculty of Medicine Siriraj Hospital, Mahidol University, Bangkok, Thailand Ultraviolet radiation (UVR) plays a role in skin photodamage through triggering various biological responses of skin cells including apoptosis, oxidative stress and melanogenesis. We previously reported that human epidermal keratinocytes (HeKn) exerted paracrine protective effects on UVB-induced DNA damage and apoptosis in melanocytes (MC). In this study, we determined the protective paracrine effects of 5 skin cell types including HeKn, human keratinocyte cell line (HaCaT), primary human dermal fibroblasts (HDF), mouse fibroblast cell line (NIH3T3) and epidermoid carcinoma (A431) on UVB-induced MC responses. The results showed that conditioned medium (CM) from 4 types of the skin cells except A431 cells reduced caspase-3 activation and ROS formation induced by UVB (250 and 62.5 mJ/cm 2 , respectively) as well as increased tyrosinase activity and melanin level in MC exposed to UVB (125 mJ/cm 2 ). In conclusion, 4 types of skin cells except A431 cells exerted modulatory paracrine effects on MC responses mediated by UVB in a different extent. HeKn provided the highest modulatory effects on UVB-induced caspase-3 activation, oxidant formation and melanogenesis in MC. Further study using systems approach (RNA-Seq and ELISA array) will be performed to identify possible paracrine factors responsible for the modulatory paracrine effects of HeKn. Disulfide bonds (DSBs), formed from two cysteine residues in proteins, are key stabilizing elements in many proteins. Changes to DSBs are postulated to play a vital role in determining the structural stability and biological activity of proteins. Kinetic analysis indicates that DSBs on proteins are significant targets for oxidants, however, relatively little is known about the oxidation of disulfides on proteins and the mechanisms of reactions that result in destruction of these residues. In the studies reported here we show that singlet oxygen ( 1 O 2 )-mediated photooxidation of beta-2-microglobulin (B2M) yields thiosulfinates [RSS(¼O)R'], which can subsequently react (after the cessation of O 2 exposure) with other thiol-containing proteins, such as glyceraldehyde 3phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH), to form B2M-GAPDH cross-links. This novel cross-linked species has been characterized by both western blotting and mass spectrometry. Other disulfide-containing proteins (e.g. C-reactive protein, alpha-lactalbumin, lysozyme) previously exposed to O 2 also react with GAPDH and human serum albumin (HSA) to form novel protein cross-links. Overall, these data indicate that photooxidation of DSBs on proteins can generate long-lived reactive intermediates (e.g. thiosulfinates), that react with thiols on other proteins to generate inter-protein cross-links. These reactions may help rationalize the accumulation of cross-linked proteins in a number of human pathologies.
body_text.section: The modulatory paracrine effects of keratinocytes on UVBmediated apoptosis, oxidative stress and melanogenesis in melanocytes

body_text.text: Jong-Sang Kim, Jisun Lim, Dongyup Han, Myung Ju Gu, Jisun Oh, Jeong Soon Lee Kyungpook National University, South Korea Our previous study showed that the ethanol extract of Dioscorea batatas Decne (Chinese yam) bark upregulated certain antioxidant enzymes through Nrf2 signaling pathway. This study was conducted to identify the compounds responsible for the antioxidant activity from Chinese yam bark extract. Bioassay-guided fractionation using HepG2-ARE cells resulted in identification of 2 kinds of phenanthrene derivatives with a strong antioxidant enzyme-inducing activity. Among them, 2, 7-dihydroxy-4, 6-dimethoxy phenanthrene (DDP) isolated from yam bark extract reduced the level of reactive oxygen species in tert-butyl hydroperoxide-challenged Raw 264.7 cells. Moreover, DDP enhanced the expression of nuclear factor (erythroid-derived 2)-like 2 (Nrf2) and its downstream heme oxygenase-1 proteins while it decreased the expression of iNOS, COX-2, proinflammatory cytokines via nuclear factor-κB pathway. In conclusion, DDP was found to have anti-inflammatory effect as well as antioxidant activity and warrants further in vivo efficacy study for future medical food use.

body_text.text: Elena Kalinina, Ahmed Alsaidi, Nikolai Chernov Peoples' Friendship University of Russia (RUDN University), Moscow, Russian Federation Among the peroxiredoxin family members peroxiredoxin 6 (Prx6) not only to reduce H 2 O 2 and phospholipid hydroperoxides but also possesses phospholipase A2 and lysophosphatidylcholine acyl transferase activities which are different exchanged in some pathologies including cancer. However, contribution of Prx6 into the regulation of oxidant/antioxidant balance, that responsible for proliferation/apoptosis switching, under tumor growth is still poor understood. Here we studied PRX6 changes as well as cellular redox state during the formation of cisplatin resistance in human ovarian carcinoma SKOV-3 cells. The development of the drug resistance found to be accompanied by the increase of PRDX6 expression and growth of GSH/GSSG ratio due to elevation of GSH level, which needs for reduction of Prx6 oxidized form, as a result of enhancement of GSH synthesis de novo. In addition, it was established that siRNA knockdown of Trx1 increased CDDP-induced death of resistant cells that was significantly rose by additively use of siRNA knockdown of Prx6. The results testify to the important role of Prx6 in redox-dependent mechanism of cancer cell resistance to cisplatin. The eye lens is an avascular organ comprised of a syncytium of cells, the vast majority of which are devoid of functional organelles. To ensure lifelong clarity, the lens relies on a high concentration of chaperone crystallin proteins and a near hypoxic core. Photooxidation of lens lipids and proteins leads to an accumulation of oxidative insults; beyond a tipping point, these develop into light-scattering aggregates which form cataracts. Lens lipid membranes contain some of the highest concentrations of cholesterol described in any organ. Here, we demonstrate an effective method of mimicking known congenital cataractogenic human diseases in the developing zebrafish by disrupting cholesterol synthesis. Further, the relationship between lens sterols and crystallin proteins underpins both cataractogenesis and the resolution of light-scattering aggregates. We have investigated the chaperone potential of α-crystallin in different lens lysate preparations, and analysed the effect of sterol Tumors rewire their cellular metabolism in order to supply building blocks needed to support their rapid proliferation and growth. However, the role of metabolic processes in regulating cancer cells' aggressiveness is still unknown. We previously identified a set of metabolic genes which expression highly correlated with known mesenchymal markers. Among these, we identified glutathione peroxidase 8 (GPx8), an endoplasmic reticulum transmembrane protein, whose physiological function is still unclear. Here, we assessed the role of GPx8 as a regulator of the cancer cell aggressiveness. We found that GPx8 up-regulation is dependent on the epithelial-to-mesenchymal (EMT) program and that in various cancers, high expression of this gene correlates with poor patient outcome. Moreover, GPx8 knockout in the breast cancer-derived cell line MDA-MB-231 resulted in an epithelial-like morphology, downregulation of EMT signature and characteristics, loss of cancer cells stemness features, and tumor initiation in mice. We identified that GPx8 regulates the expression and secretion of several key autocrine factors promoting tumor aggressiveness, including IL-6. Thus, GPX8 loss compromises IL-6receptor signaling, resulting in cancer cells stemness impairment. Therefore, GPx8 regulates the transition of cancer cells to a more aggressive state, demonstrating the role of redox signalling in tumour progression.

body_text.text: Sung Hwan Kim, Jeen-Woo Park
body_text.section: Oxalomalate reduces tumor progression in melanoma

body_text.text: The potent cytotoxicity of reactive oxygen species (ROS) can cause various diseases, however, it may also serve as a powerful chemotherapeutic strategy capable of killing cancer cells. Oxalomalate (OMA, α-hydroxy-β-oxalosuccinic acid), a tricarboxylic acid intermediate, is a well-known competitive inhibitor of two classes of NADPþ-dependent isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) isoenzymes, which serve as the major antioxidants and redox regulators in the mitochondria and cytosol. In this study, we investigated the therapeutic effects of OMA in melanoma and elucidated the associated underlying mechanisms of action using in vitro and in vivo models. OMA targeting IDH enzymes suppressed melanoma growth through activation of apoptosis and inhibition of angiogenesis. Mechanistically, our findings showed that OMA activated p53-mediated apoptosis through ROS-dependent ATM-Chk2 signaling and reduced the expression of vascular endothelial growth factor through ROS-dependent E2F1-mediated hypoxia inducible factor-1α degradation. In particular, OMA-induced suppression of IDH activity resulted in induction of ROS stress response, ultimately leading to apoptotic cell death and antiangiogenic effects in melanoma cells. Thus, OMA might be a potential candidate drug for melanoma skin cancer therapy.

body_text.section: Metabolic status of neutrophils of patients with the toxic nephropathy

body_text.text: Purpose of the study: To assess the metabolic status of neutrophils in the blood of patients with nephropathy with the toxic kidney damage. Two groups of patients were identified: group 1patients with acetic acid poisoning and toxic kidney damage, group 2patients with acetic acid poisoning without kidney damage. In neutrophils, the activity of catalase, myeloperoxidase (MPO) and the concentration of AOPP were determined. A significant decrease in catalase activity was found in both groups. The activity of MPO in patients of group 1 was significantly reduced. MPO activity in patients of group 2 remained within control values. A significant increase in the level of AOPP in the neutrophils of patients of both groups. Conclusion: Based on the data obtained, we suggested that peripheral blood neutrophils were involved in the mechanisms of progression of kidney damage in case of poisoning. The decrease in the activity of enzymes involved in the implementation of the protective function of neutrophils (MPO), could indicate their inactivation or depletion of their adaptive potential. Thus, blood neutrophils were shown to be involved in the development of functional kidney damage when exposed to a non-specific toxic agent (acetic acid).

body_text.section: Ron Kohen

body_text.text: Skin, the largest organ in our body, is exposed to various exogenous and endogenous stress-inducing conditions challenging its homeostasis. One of the most important cellular defence mechanisms by which human skin copes with these numerous stressors is the Nrf2-keap1 defence system. All stressors share the same downstream effect within skin cells: increasing reactive oxygen species (ROS) concentrations leading either to induction of oxidative damage (excessive production) or beneficial effect by activating the protective Nrf2-keap1 pathway (moderate production). Our premise is that the defence mechanisms of skin should always be active and alert. We hypothesized that skin microbiome and their metabolites and environmental moderate stressors are responsible for keeping the skin Nrf2-keap1 pathway partially induced and ready to cope with various insults. It has been shown that activation of the Nrf2-keap1 pathway is mediated partially by the presence of skin microbiome via its volatile organic electrophiles. Environmental stressors such as unique UV radiation, osmotic pressure, high temperatures can activate this pathway using different mechanisms. Skin's defence mechanism is kept under tight regulation and always in an alert condition to cope with stress. Moderate exposure to such stress conditions is beneficial for the human body.
body_text.section: Ron Kohen

body_text.text: Fatty liver disease is a progressive metabolic disorder characterized, among other features, by accumulation of excessive lipids, leading to hepatocellular dysfunction. Despite extensive research, the role of autophagy in the development of fatty liver disease remains controversial, as autophagy regulates lipid metabolism and lipid droplet degradation. Transcription factor Nrf2 plays a protective role in fatty liver disease by regulating antioxidant defenses and lipogenic genes, which promote hepatosteatosis. However, the role of Nrf2, autophagy and their molecular crosstalk under lipotoxic conditions is incompletely defined. The purpose of this study is to investigate the cross regulation of autophagy and Nrf2-Keap1 pathway under lipotoxic conditions and to estimate their involvement in lipid droplet formation and cellular dysfunction. Therefore, we induced lipid accumulation in HepG2 cells by exposing them to palmitic acid (PA). According to our study, autophagy plays a key role in the lipid droplet content. Western blot analysis of autophagy-related proteins revealed an impairment of the autophagic flux. Additionally, immunocytochemistry and western blot analysis indicated increased p62 levels and activation of Nrf2/Keap1 pathway. Under these conditions, Nrf2 knockdown experiments are being performed to elucidate the impact of Nrf2 on lipid droplet formation and autophagy.
body_text.section: The role of autophagy and Nrf2 in palmitate-induced hepatocellular damage

body_text.text: 102. Automated immuno-histo-enzymatic investigation of metabolic enzyme activity in skin and organotypic skin models shows epidermal metabolism regulation by metformin Christopher Kremslehner 1,5 , Anne Miller 2 , Robert Nica 3 , Francesca Ferrara 4 , Julia Lachner 1 , Maria Gschwandtner 1 , Ionela-Mariana Nagelreiter 1,5 , Erwin Tschachler 1 , Michael Mildner 1 , Arvand Haschemi 2 , Florian Gruber Metabolic activity of cells in tissues depends on type, nutrient availability, position, differentiation state, and other parameters. We developed an automated microscopy method that relates the cell individual enzymatic activity to marker expression and position within the epidermis. We adapted StrataQuest software (Tissuegnostics) to detect the epidermis and its strata based on nuclear density mapping and distance-based algorithms. The sections were IF-stained for differentiation and proliferation markers. The activity assay for the enzymes G6PD and GAPDH was performed with enzyme specific substrates and a tetrazolium based chromogenic dye. We could predict with high precision the basal, first suprabasal and stratum corneum layers of human epidermis and in organotypic skin equivalents and verify the differentiation state with markers. We could assign enzymatic activity of G6PD to single cells within the predicted strata. Addition of Metformin two days before harvest led to a significant increase in G6PD activity, whereas UVB pre-exposure of embedded Kerantinocytes led to reduced G6PD activity. In conclusion, we were able to present an automated assay for epidermal image analysis and could prove responsiveness of metabolic enzyme activity to Metformin which is not only used for treatment of diabetes but also the most investigated anti-aging drug.

Green tea epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG) oxidative stress and DNA damage Carina Ladeira 1,2 , M ario P adua 1 , Carina Ramos 3 , Edna Ribeiro Epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG) antioxidant properties have been demonstrated however, increasing evidence indicates that EGCG produces reactive oxygen species. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of EGCG intake during 90 days in hematological cardiovascular risk factors, vitamins A and E, DNA damage and oxidative damage in human blood. Peripheral blood from 30 healthy individuals (10 males and 20 females; 18 -45 years), was collected at time 0 (T0) and time 90 (T90). During 90 days, participant's ingested capsules of green tea extract (225mg EGCG) daily. Hematological cardiovascular risk factors including lipid profile and liver function parameters were assessed using colorimetric methods. Vitamins A and E in serum were quantified by HPLC and analysis of DNA damage and oxidative damage was performed by comet assay. Our results showed that lipid profile and liver function parameters are not affected by EGCG and serum levels of vitamin E increased, but not vitamin A. An increase of DNA damage and DNA oxidative damage after 90 days of EGCG consumption was also reported. The results suggest that EGCG can induce DNA damage, possibly due to ROS induction, with associated increase of the antioxidant vitamin E, however without alteration of hematological cardiovascular risk factors. Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) reflects a spectrum of chronic liver diseases characterized by hepatic fat accumulation. Apolipoprotein O (ApoO) is a new member of the apolipoprotein family that may play a role in lipid metabolism and mitochondrial electron transport activity. We hypothesized that hepatic expression of ApoO is tightly linked not only to diet-induced hepatosteatosis, but also to oxidative stress and hormones. Therefore, we compared the effects of lipid loading on ApoO regulation in chicken (LMH) with those in human (HepG2) hepatoma cells. Incubation with oleic acid (OA) induced triglyceride accumulation, but did not affect cell viability. RT-qPCR and Western blot analyses showed significant increase in ApoO transcript and protein levels in both cell lines. Oxidative stress applied by H 2 O 2 revealed induction of ApoO in the same or even higher extent as monitored by OA. ApoO increased upon treatment with estrogen supporting the assumption that estrogen affects lipoprotein metabolism. Furthermore, both cell lines showed a significant decrease of the mitochondrial membrane potential upon incubation with OA. We assume that our findings support a role of ApoO as an effector of compromised mitochondrial function that likely accompanies the onset of NAFLD. Ferritin has intrinsic ascorbate oxidase activity that is increased by low iron activities. UV irradiation of horse spleen ferritin solutions, buffered in citrate-(1mM), MOPS (50 mM), pH 7.0 at 295K with ascorbate (2.5mM) has contrasting effects when irradiated with UVC (250 nm) and UVA (360 nm). UVC irradiation generates a ferritin saturable increase in ascorbate oxidase (AO) activity, observed by a transient increase in EPR monitored ascorbate radical formation. This is followed by ascorbate peroxidase (AP) activity, seen as a steady decrease in ascorbate radical signal. In contrast UVA elicits no observable ascorbate oxidase activity but instead generates immediate ferritin saturable AP activity. In anaerobic conditions the UVC-dependent ferritin AO activity is abolished, but AP activity remains. With UVA the anaerobic AP activity is approximately 10x more active than with UVC. Catalase abolishes anaerobic ferritin-dependent AP activity with UVA and UVC irradiation but with both UVC and UVA, a low rate of AO is revealed. These tuneable UV dependent intrinsic ferritin ascorbate oxidase and peroxidase activities and their variable responses to low concentrations of ferrous ions are similar to those found with metal-based nanomaterials and may explain the intense inflammatory responses elicited by UV irradiation in skin cells. Frataxin deficiency is the pathogenic cause of Friedreich's Ataxia, an autosomal recessive disease characterized by the increase of oxidative stress and production of free radicals in the cell. The onset of the pathology occurs in the second decade of life, however, cognitive differences and defects in brain structure and functional activation are observed in patients, suggesting developmental defects to take place during fetal neurogenesis. Here we describe impairments in proliferation, stemness potential and differentiation in neural stem cells isolated from the embryonic cortex of the Frataxin Knockin/Knockout mouse, a disease animal model whose slow-evolving phenotype makes it suitable to study pre-symptomatic defects that may manifest before the clinical onset. At molecular level, KIKO NSCs show protein and mRNA reduction of the transcription factor Nrf2 and, consequently, of its target genes. We demonstrate that by treating KIKO NSCs with two different antioxidant molecules, the rescue of Nrf2 and Nrf2-target gene expression occurs both in proliferating NSCs and in differentiation conditions. Although only partial restore of KIKO NSCs proliferation and clonogenicity is observed upon Nrf2 induction, antioxidant treatments are able to reestablish a proper differentiation program and rescue of neuronal complexity of FRDA neurons.

body_text.section: Oxidative modifications of proteins in blood plasma of patients with drug-induced nephropathies

body_text.text: The kidney is required to perform regulation of the extracellular environment, such as detoxification, and excretion of toxic metabolites and drugs. Nephrotoxicity is a kidney-specific feature in which excretion does not go smoothly owing to drugs. Approximately 20% of nephrotoxocity is induced by drugs. Our research goal was to explore oxidative modifications of proteins: advanced oxidation protein products (AOPP) in serum (Witko-Sarsat et al, 1996) , reactive protein carbonyl derivatives RPCD in blood plasma and erythrocytes (Levine et al, 1990) of patients with drug-induced nephropathies (were detected with neutrophil gelatinase associated lipocalin). There were 70 patients divided into 2 groups: the first group was represented by patients with psychotropic drug-induced nephropathy; the second onepatients with nephropathy caused by nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). The control group consisted of 30 healthy subjects. AOPP concentration was the highest in serum of the 2nd group (p<0.002). The RPCD level in blood plasma of the 1st group was lower in comparison with control one (p<0.001). Though reverse results were shown in erythrocytes: RPCD level significantly increased (p<0.001) in the second group. Proceeding from these results we suppose that the patterns of oxidized proteins could be varied depending on the type of the drug-induced nephropathy.

body_text.text: Activating mutations in BRAF protein (BRAFV600) are found in more than 50% of melanoma. Vemurafenib (PLX4032), specific BRAF-mutated inhibitor, is used routinely in chemotherapy, relapses can occur. Since heme oxygenase-1 (HO-1) is involved in chemo-resistance in different tumors, we have evaluated its role in limiting the efficacy of PLX4032 in melanoma under physiological normoxia and hypoxia. Moreover, the role of HIF-1α and the angiogenic potential of melanoma cells after treatment has been analyzed. In this study, primary melanoma cell line (MeOV-1) was exposed to PLX4032. HO-1 was modulated by genesilencing or using tin-mesoporphyrin IX (SnMP-IX). Bovine aortic endothelial cells (BAEC) were used to evaluate the angiogenic potential of MeOV-1 supernatant. MeOV-1 cells were maintained and adapted longterm (5d) in an O2-regulated workstation under physiological normoxia and hypoxia (respectively 5-1 kPa O2). Adaptation to physiological normoxia/hypoxia didn`t affect the sensitivity of MeOV-1 cells to PLX4032 (reduction of cell viability of 45% and upregulation of HO-1), whereas PLX4032 significantly downregulated HIF-1α protein expression. Furthermore, treatment of BAEC with the supernatant from PLX4032 treated MeOV-1 cells resulted in increased tube formation, branching and density. Our findings highlight an important role for HO-1 in favoring melanoma resistance to target therapy and promoting angiogenesis. Exogenous cannabinoids, mainly phytocannabinoids, such as cannabidiol, which is not psychoactive, but has anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, may be suggested for the treatment of skin diseases. Therefore, the aim of presented study was to investigate the cannabidiol effect on ceramide profile of keratinocytes from patients with psoriasis vulgaris cultured in vitro. Lipid extracts were analyzed by RPLC-Q-TOF-MS to characterize ceramide profiles. Ceramide species responsible for changes in the profiles were selected by use of univariate and multivariate statistics. The relative abundances of sphingosine ceramides and dihydroceramides were decreased (~9-12% and~8-17%, respectively), whereas abundance of phytoceramides was increased (~7-24%) in keratinocytes from patients with psoriasis compared with cells from healthy subject. By contrast, decreased (~6-19%) relative levels of phytoceramides, especially those with long acyl chains were observed in keratinocytes from psoriatic patients after treatment with cannabidiol. Our study provides insights into the alterations of the keratinocytes ceramide profile in the development of psoriasis and may indicate the role of cannabidiol in regulation of keratinocyte membranes permeability. This study was financed by NCN Poland grant no. 2016/23/B/NZ7/ 02350. Cooperation between coauthors is financed by the Polish National Agency for Academic Exchange (NAWA), as part of the International Academic Partnerships (PPI/APM/2018/00015/U/001). The mitochondrion is called the powerhouse of the cell for good reason since it is responsible for satisfying the energy demands of most mammalian. This is achieved through the provision of ATP, which is made through the oxidation of various fuels and the establishment of a protonmotive force by the electron transport chain. Fuel combustion for ATP production is finely tuned in response to changes in cell energy demands. Importantly, electron fluxes in mitochondria must also be tightly regulated to safeguard cells from reactive oxygen species; molecules that are toxic at high levels but beneficial when generated in a controlled manner. Our group has found that a cysteine switch called "protein S-glutathionylation" plays a vital role in modulating the bioenergetics of mitochondria in several tissues. Here, I will present new findings from our group demonstrating that manipulating mitochondrial redox signals through deletion of the glutaredoxin-2 gene protects mice from diet-induced obesity and related disorders. This is associated with increased proton leaks, fuel burning, and ROS handling in muscle. Our findings suggest that targeted alteration of mitochondrial glutathionylation patterns may serve as a means to prevent/reverse obesity.

It is formed by oxidation of xanthine and the reaction is catalyzed by xanthine oxidase, a molybdenum-iron sulfur flavoprotein. Mo is the functional center for this enzyme involved in the regulation of adenosine and its metabolites are important markers of ischemia. 30 atherosclerotic plaques of coronary arteries of hyperuricemic patients were analysed with FT-IR spectroscopy and SEM-EDX microscopy. The intensity of the band at 3270 cm-1 suggested that the atherosclerotic plaques contained a higher number of NH2 groups, and it was related with increased levels of uric acid in blood serum. The intensity of the band at 1735 cm-1 confirmed the formation of malondialdehyde. The intensity decrease of the bands in the region 1650-1500 cm-1 was associated with the decrease of ApoI/ApoII ratio. The band at 1467 cm-1 indicated the presence of urea components; result of the metabolic pathway. SEM-EDX analysis showed fibril formation and molybdenum (Mo) release in hyperuricemic patients. These findings indicate that superoxide anions reduce Mo cations to lower valance leading to inhibition of xanthine oxidase activity. body_text.text: Urban air pollution exposure is associated with increased mortality rates, mainly due to myocardial infarction (MI). In order to study the mechanisms underlying this observation, BALB/c mice were exposed to filtered air (FA, control) or urban air (UA) inside whole-body inhalation chambers located in Buenos Aires City, and subjected to MI after 12 weeks. Mice breathing UA showed increased BAL leucocyte count and protein concentration, together with increased TNF-α and MCP-1 levels. Consistently, lung histology showed thickening of the alveolar wall and inflammatory leukocyte recruitment. BAL analysis by flow cytometry showed enhanced alveolar macrophage activation in UA-exposed mice. In this group, a significant increase in plasma TNF-α was also observed. At this time point, UA exposure lead to enhanced ischemia/reperfusion injury. Mechanistically, UAexposed mice showed impaired cardiac mitochondrial function, characterized by ultrastructural abnormalities, decreased active state respiration, inner membrane depolarization, increased O

Our results indicate that a chronic exposure to UA induces a degree of lung inflammation that impairs mitochondrial function in distant organs, such as the heart, which worsens MI outcome. Taken together, our data highlights the importance of considering environmental factors in the development of cardiovascular diseases in urban areas. In the present communication, we show different experimental approaches used in our group for the characterization of the effects of anti-angiogenic compounds on the redox state of endothelial and tumor cells. Proteomics, Western blotting, determination of antioxidant enzyme activities and evaluation of global anti-oxidant potentials allow us to dissect the concrete involvement of anti-angiogenic compounds on the redox biology of the studied cells. We illustrate this approach with results obtained with the anti-angiogenic compounds homocysteine, aeroplysinin-1 and dimethyl fumarate. Loss-of-function mutations of KRIT1/CCM1 predispose to familial cerebral cavernous malformation disease (CCM). It has been evidenced that KRIT1 loss-of function causes alterations of basal anti-oxidant and antiglycative responses. However, extracerebral phenotype of KRIT1 mutation has been poorly investigated. We previously demonstrated that a high-fructose diet generates oxidative stress and advanced glycation endproducts (AGEs) in tissues, including liver and brain, leading to altered lipid metabolism and inflammation. We thus investigated whether KRIT1 loss-of-function may worsen the high-fructose dietinduced hepatic dysmetabolism. KRIT1-silenced and -overexpressing cultured MEFs revealed marked modulation of the lipid synthesizing enzymes. In parallel, KRIT1 loss-offunction in heterozygous knockout mice (EZ) was sufficient to induce hepatosteatosis with impaired expression of enzymes involved in lipid synthesis and of AGEs-receptors and -detoxifying enzyme glyoxalase-1. A high-fructose diet administered to EZ mice for 22 weeks further enhanced lipid accumulation in liver and alterations of the AGEs receptors RAGE, AGE-R1 and galectin-3 and of glyoxalase-1, inducing a fibrogenic response. Our results indicate that the metabolic burden exerted by the fructose diet in heterozygous KRIT1 knockout mice further aggravates dysmetabolism, possibly involving glycative stress, suggesting that an unbalanced nutrition in CCM patients may result in worse metabolic disturbances than in general population.

body_text.text: Faculty of Medicine, University of Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia Clinic of otorhinolaringolgy, Clinical center of Serbia, Belgrade, Serbia 4 Medical laboratory "PAN LAB", Kraljevo, Serbia Introduction: Balkan endemic nephropathy (BEN) is a form of chronic tubulointersticial nephritis leading to end stage renal disease (ESRD). Clinical data indicate the significant role of antioxidant enzymes superoxide dismutase (SOD2) and glutathione peroxidase (GPX1) polymorphisms in the development of ESRD. Aim: To examine the association of SOD2 and GPX1 polymorphisms with BEN risk and its associated tumors. Material and Methods: This case-control study was conducted in 207 BEN patients and 86 controls from endemic areas. SOD2 rs4880 polymorphism was analyzed using qPCR while GPX1 rs1050450 polymorphism was analyzed using PCR-RFLP. Results: Obtained results have shown that individuals with both variant SOD2 allele are at 2.6 higher BEN risk (OR¼2.6, 95% CI: 1.15-5.85, p¼0.021). Polymorphic expression of GPX1 is, neither independently nor combined with SOD2 variant genotype, significantly associated with BEN risk (p˂0.05). Regarding the risk of urothelial tumors in BEN patients, none of the polymorphisms studied was significantly associated with risk of these tumors in BEN patients (p˂0.05). Conclusion: It may be concluded that SOD2 enzyme might be an important player in preventing excessive superoxide accumulation in mitochondrial distress and induction of programmed cell death in kidneys during BEN development.

The nitration of fibrinogen by ONOOis a potential biomarker. A mass spectrometry approach was developed to evaluate the nitration of fibrinogen and its implication in ischaemic stroke. A mapping of 3-nitrotyrosine and a relative quantification of it were made. Twenty different tyrosine residues were identified as nitration targets, after treatment with ONOO -. The number of 3-nitrotyrosine residues and the abundance of those showed to vary in a ONOOconcentration-dependent manner. The fibrinogen chains have different susceptibility to nitration. Nine peptides were found to be more frequently modified and their peptidespecific transitions were chosen to perform a targeted analysis in clinical samples. Three of the nine peptides showed a significative difference between stroke and control. The nitration pattern in-vitro is not the same as the one in-vivo. We aimed to study the role of glutathione peroxidase (GPx) on cytosol and membrane of red blood cells (RBCs) when catalase (CAT) is impaired. We performed in vitro assays (n¼4) by incubating RBCs from healthy volunteers with increasing H2O2 concentrations (0, 15, 30, 60μM) while inhibiting CAT (sodium azide). The cytosol activity of GPx, reduced and oxidized glutathione ratio (GSH/GSSG) and RBC membrane lipid peroxidation (LPO) were evaluated by spectrophotometry; GPx amount in RBC membrane was determined by westernblot.

body_text.text: In the RBC cytosol, GPx activity decreased as H2O2 concentration increased; simultaneously, we found decreasing GSH/GSSG. At the RBC membrane, we detected increasing linkage of GPx with increasing H2O2 concentrations; LPO values increased when H2O2 was added, however for 30 and 60μM of H2O2 no differences were found. Our results show that in the cytosol, GPx activity seems to be less effective as H2O2 concentration increases probably due to an accumulation of GSSG, as GSH regeneration is slow in the RBC. GPx binding to the RBC membrane with increasing H2O2 is most likely an effort to protect the membrane as GPx can remove hydroperoxides, contributing to LPO prevention.

body_text.text: The metastasis suppressor, N-myc downstream regulated gene-1 (NDRG1), is a stress response protein that is downregulated in cancers and this correlates with poorly differentiated, advanced cancers. It inhibits multiple oncogenic pathways and is upregulated by hypoxia, DNA damage or iron depletion. Initial studies have linked NDRG1 and the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress response. Considering this, we extensively examined the mechanism by which NDRG1 regulates the ER stress response in pancreatic and colon cancer cells. The expression of NDRG1 was demonstrated to regulate the three main arms of the ER stress response by: (1) increasing the expression of three major ER chaperones, BiP, calreticulin, and calnexin; (2) suppressing the PERK pathway;
body_text.section: Catalase inhibition leads to translocation of glutathione peroxidase to the erythrocyte membrane

body_text.text: (3) inhibiting the IRE1α arm; and (4) increasing ATF6 cleavage. An important finding was that NDRG1 enhances the antiproliferative and anti-migratory activity of the anti-cancer chelator, Dp44mT. This increased efficacy could be related to the following effects in the presence of Dp44mT and NDRG1: activation of eIF2α; high cytosolic Ca þ2 that increases apoptosis sensitivity; activation of CaMKII signaling; and increased pro-apoptotic CHOP. Collectively, this investigation dissects the mechanisms through which NDRG1 manipulates the ER stress response and its ability to potentiate the activity of the potent anti-cancer agent, Dp44mT.

Hence, studies examined the mechanisms by which TCs alter the UPR in multiple cancer cells to suppress cancer proliferation and migration. These studies established that TCs significantly induced high levels of ER stress, increasing the activation of pro-apoptotic UPR signals (i.e., p-CAMKII, CHOP), while suppressing UPR survival signals (e.g., XBP1s, p58IPK). In contrast, redox inactive agent DFO and the ER stressinducing drug, tunicamycin, had little or no effect on these proteins. Moreover, it was demonstrated that anti-oxidants could inhibit TCmediated activation of the UPR, while pro-oxidants enhanced activity. Silencing the UPR reduced TC-mediated pro-apoptotic activity and migration inhibition. In conclusion, the induction of lethal ER stress via iron sequestration and the generation of ROS is crucial for the anti-cancer activity of TCs. Alterations of intracellular redox homeostasis, with the enhancement of glutathione (GSH) levels, and the presence of cancer stem cells (CSCs) are critically involved in chemoresistance. Moreover, CSCs express CD44 which is a staminality marker modulated by PKC-α and which is able to influence GSH content by stabilizing xCT, a cystine-glutamate antiporter promoting GSH synthesis. The aim of this study is to investigate the role of CD44/xCT in the sensitivity of CSCs to etoposide, an anticancer drug with pro-oxidant effects. Therefore, CSCs were selected from HTLA-230, a human neuroblastoma cell line, and from etoposide-resistant HTLA (HTLA-ER) cells, and then were treated with etoposide alone or in combination with sulfasalazine (SSZ), an xCT inhibitor, or with C2-4, a PKC-α inhibitor. A 5-week treatment of HTLA-ER CSCs with SSZ or C2-4 plus etoposide reduced cell propagation and GSH levels, also promoting glycolysis and lipoperoxidation whereas similar effects were observed in HTLA-230 CSCs after 2 weeks of etoposide and were not modified by either co-treatments. Collectively, our data demonstrates that targeting CD44/xCT, by reducing GSH levels, favors glycolytic metabolism, induces oxidative damage and could be an effective strategy for counteracting CSC chemoresistance (Grants from Genoa University).

In this study, germ-free (GF) and conventional mice (C57/BL6) were fed a Western-diet and received a NOS inhibitor (L-NAME, 1g/l) in combination with either nitrate (NaNO , 10mM) or placebo (NaCl, 10mM) in the drinking water. Weekly body weigh monitoring was followed by blood pressure (tail cuff), glucose tolerance (IPGTT) and body composition (DEXA) measurements. During the six weeks of treatment, conventional and GF mice within the placebo group gained weight and showed increased blood pressure, impaired glucose tolerance and fatty liver. As expected, nitrate protected conventional mice from the effects of a Western-diet and L-NAME. However, no nitrate-like effect was detected in the absence of host bacteria.

Sulforaphane induced Nrf2 activation attenuates adiposity and glucose intolerance in obese insulin-resistant murine pregnancy With age, senescent cells that contribute to chronic inflammation and age-related functional decline, accumulate in tissues. The senescence associated secretory phenotype (SASP), a cocktail of inflammatory cyto/ chemokines and matrix proteases conveys the sescent cell signalling. However, the knowledge on lipid mediators which we recently discovered as members of the SASP is limited. We investigated whether the composition and amount of bioactive lipid mediators are altered in senescent fibroblasts. Using mass spectrometry lipidomics, we identified two lysophosphatidylcholines (1-palmitoyl-2-hydroxy-sn-glycero-3phosphocholine and 1-stearoyl-2-hydroxy-sn-glycero-3-phosphocholine; lyso-PCs) to be significantly elevated in replicative-, and stress induced premature-senescence of human dermal fibroblasts and we were able to detect the same lipid species in cell supernatants. Telomerase transduced fibroblasts did not display elevated lyso-PCs even at high population doublings. When we exposed FB to lyso-PC, we found elevated expression and secretion of the chemokines CXCL1 and IL8. In monocyte lineage cells, however, lyso-PCs disturbed TLR2/6-CD36 signaling by the agonist FSL1 and uptake of labeled dextrane and therefore may interfere with the recognition of senescent cells. Thus, we propose that lyso-PCs contribute to the chronic pro-inflammatory environment not only directly, but also indirectly, by disturbing the clearance of senescent cells.

body_text.text: It has been shown that CD44v6 and Nm23-H1 genes play a crucial role in the metastasis of various cancers. However, no study has been done on the effect of epigenetic factors on the expression of CD44v6 and Nm23-H1 genes in the lung cancer cell line, A549.Therefore, the present study investigated the role of a histone deacetylase inhibitor, valproic acid, on the expression of CD44v6 and Nm23-H1 genes and proteins in the A549 cell line. In this study, the A549 cell line was treated with valproic acid at concentrations of 2.2 mM, 4.5 mM, and 9 mM. We then investigated the expression of CD44v6 and Nm23-H1 genes and proteins, as well as the expression of MMP-2 and MMP-9 genes and caspase-3 activity. The results showed that valproic acid significantly decreased the expression of CD44v6 gene and protein and MMP-2 and MMP-9 genes, but increased the expression of Nm23-H1 gene and protein and the activity of caspase-3 (p < 0.05). Our results showed that histone deacetylases affected the expression of CD44v6, Nm23-H1, MMP-2, and MMP-9, which are involved in metastasis. Therefore, the use of histone deacetylase inhibitors can be effective in the suppression of metastases and the treatment of lung cancer.

Phospholipid-bound oxidized fatty acids inhibit LPS-induced inflammatory reactions more efficiently than the same oxidized fatty acids in their free forms Objective: Diabetes mellitus is a common endocrine metabolic disorder. The aim of this study was to evaluate the nuclear morphologic analysis in buccal epithelial cells using an exfoliative cytology in type 2 diabetic patients. Study Design: We performed light microscopic analysis of the buccal smears in thirty type 2 diabetics and thirty healthy individuals. The buccal smears were stained with Papanicolaou stain by using light microscopy (OlympusBX-51). In each case, the mean nuclear area, perimeter, length and width were evaluated in each smear using the image analysis software (Q Win, Leica™). Statistical analysis was performed with SPSS 19.0 software (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA). p<0.05 was considered as statistically significant. Results: The nuclear area, perimeter and width were not statistically significant between the type 2 diabetics and the control groups. Only nuclear height was significantly higher in the diabetic group than that of the control group (p< 0.05).

Nowadays more than 90% of the urban population live with pollutant levels exceeding WHO standard limits and because of its critical location, the skin acts as a biological shield against various chemical/physical outdoor stressors, like environmental pollution. The protective ability of the skin is not unlimited and problems arise when this exposure exceeds its defensive potential. Recently a new player in the inflammation mechanism was discovered: the multi-protein complex inflammasome, a cytosolic receptor expressed also in keratinocytes that senses the environment and ultimately releases the pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-1β and IL-18. Among the several stimuli involved in the inflammasome activation there is the altered redox-homeostasis, which along inflammation, represents the common denominator of the development of several skin diseases. The topical application of natural compounds like blueberries has been proven successful to reduce skin-inflammation: our preliminary data shows that in keratinocytes, 3D models and human skinbiopsies, exposure to ozone induces gene expression and protein levels of several inflammasome-related markers. Pretreatment with blueberry extract, instead, decreases this expression, enhances epithelial woundhealing and reduce the formation of the oligomer-scaffold necessary for inflammasome activity. We hypothesize that blueberry extract can effectively reduce skin-inflammation therefore could be recommended as preventive approach against cutaneous pollution-induced damage. We have isolated and characterized total plasma EVs (pEVs). We found that the concentrations of APP, Aß42, tTau and pTau-T181 were higher in pEVs than in plasma. Our results revealed that the concentrations of these AD-related proteins in the circulating EVs display a differential profile in MCI and in AD. Moreover, in AD, their levels differ with the progression of the disease. We also found an association of these AD-related proteins from pEVs with cognitive performance. The ROC analysis revealed that the levels of APP in pEVs present a good diagnostic accuracy to discriminate controls from MCI or AD groups.

While estrogen receptor α cancers are more receptive to hormonal therapy, triple negative breast cancers (TNBC) are characterized by an aggressive behaviour and the lack of targeted therapeutic strategies. Sirtuin 3 (Sirt3), a major mitochondrial NAD þ -dependent deacetylase, has bifunctional role in cancer tumorigenesis depending on the tissue and cancer-type specific metabolic programs. Due to strikingly reduced Sirt3 level in many breast cancer cells, we hypothesized it would have tumor suppressive effect in TNBC cells. Therefore, we stably transfected MDA-MB-231 cells with Flag-tagged Sirt-3 or empty plasmid and exposed cell to hyperoxic treatment. We are checking the expression of the proteins involved in mitochondrial biogenesis, metabolic regulation and antioxidant defence. Furthermore, we are investigating growth rate, metabolic activity and mitochondrial function through cellular respiration and FACS analysis. The surprising finding that Sirt-3 markedly promoted metabolic activity of TNBC cells, but reduced their potential to form new colonies and induced the mitochondrial ROS production compared to control cells gave us a rationale for more detailed studies on Sirt3 and hyperoxia as an adjuvant tumor therapy in TNBC cells. Cytosolic glutathione S-transferases (GSTs) might affect both the development and the progression of clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC). Namely, conjugation of xenobiotics with glutathione may not necessarily result in detoxification, but instead in bioactivation, especially in the kidney. Additionaly, there are evidence on the involvement of GSTs, especially GSTP1, in the cellular survival, proliferation and apoptosis. In order to elucidate the possible role of GSTP1 in ccRCC, GSTP1 genotypes (rs1695 and rs1138272) were determined in 204 RCC patients and 280 matched-controls, in whom overall survival was also evaluated. The expression of GSTP1, regulatory (JNK1/2) and executor (Caspase-3) apoptotic molecules in ccRCC tissue samples were analyzed by immunoblot. The presence of GSTP1:JNK1/2 protein:protein interaction was determined by immunoprecipitation. GSTP1-variant genotype (rs1695) was significantly associated with the risk of ccRCC development and almost 2-fold increased hazard ratio in prediction of overall mortality. Haplotype C (*Val105þ*Val114) was associated with 4-fold increased ccRCC risk. The presence of GSTP1:JNK1/2 protein:protein interaction was found in all ccRCC tissue samples studied. It might be concluded that GSTP1 polymorphisms might be associated with ccRCC risk, while the presence of GSTP1:JNK1 protein:protein interaction might be the possible molecular mechanism underlying the role of GSTP1 in ccRCC progression.

N-acetylcysteine (NAC) affects the activity of glutathione peroxidase (GPX) and reductase (GR) in the liver of wfs1-deficient mouse Antioxidative defence system is governed mainly by glutathione and the enzymes involved in the metabolism of GSH. Oxidative stress is associated with several pathological conditions. Mutations in the WFS1 gene cause wolframin deficiency, which lead to multiple complications, including oxidative stress. Wolframin, a glycoprotein located in endoplasmic reticulum, regulates calcium homeostasis, and folding of proteins. NAC is a commonly used broad range medication and a known antioxidant. The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of NAC on the activity of antioxidative enzymes GPx and GR in the liver of 2-and 6-month old Wfs1þ/þ, Wfs1þ/-and Wfs1-/-mice. We have previously shown that the administration of NAC affects the levels of GSH. The results indicate that the activity of GPx and GR affected by the administration of NAC depends on the progression of the disease. In younger mice the activity of GPx increases in Wfs1-/-mice and GR activity remains unchanged. In older mice GPx activity remains unchanged in Wfs1þ/þ, but decreased in Wfs1þ/-and Wfs1-/-mice. GR activity is decreased in Wfs1þ/-mice. The activity of GPx and GR affected by the administration of NAC may be associate with different stages of pathological process in Wfs1-deficiency.

Metabolic adaptations in spontaneously immortalized PGC-1α knock-out mouse embryonic fibroblasts increase their oncogenic potential PGC-1α controls, the capacity of cells to respond to changing nutritional requirements and energetic demands. The key role of metabolic reprogramming in tumor development has highlighted the potential role of PGC-1α in cancer. To investigate how PGC-1α impacts tumor development we used the 3T3 protocol to generate iMEFs from WT and PGC-1α KO mice. We found that PGC-1α KO iMEFs formed larger and more proliferative primary tumors than WT's, and fostered the formation of metastasis. These characteristics were associated with the reduced capacity of KO iMEFs to respond to cell contact inhibition, increased ability to form colonies in soft agar, enhanced migratory capacity, and reduced growth factor dependence. These changes are associated with higher levels of nuclear β-catenin and c-myc in KO iMEFs. Evaluation of the metabolic adaptations identified a decrease in oxidative metabolism and an increase in glycolytic flux in KO iMEFs, which were also more dependent on glutamine. Glucose oxidation and TCA forward flux were reduced in KO iMEF, resulting in the induction of anaplerotic pathways. Analysis of aminoacids and lipids patterns supported the efficient use of TCA intermediates to synthesize lipids and proteins to support cell growth rates. These characteristics support a tumor suppressor role for PGC-1α.

Hypothyroidism-induced MnSOD relocalization in early premeiotic germ cells in rat testes University of Belgrade-Institute for Biological Research "Sinisa Stankovic", Serbia Thyroid hormones affect male fertility regulating both, steroidogenesis and spermatogenesis. Hypothyroidism in rats, from birth to adulthood, is associated with delayed maturation of the testis, impaired spermatogenesis, germ cells decline, and reduced seminiferous tubule diameter. Also, due to metabolically altered state testis is much more susceptible to oxidative stress, and high level of malondialdehyde, lipid hydroperoxide and hydrogen peroxide has been demonstrated. The importance of the manganese superoxide dismutase (MnSOD) in controlling O À leakage from testicular mitochondria is well known, while its expression has been shown only in early post-meiotic germ cells. Hence, we aimed in this study to examine MnSOD immunolocalization in testes of hypothyroid rats. Two months old male Wistar rats were treated with methimazole for 7, 15 or 21 days. Control group received tap drinking water. Using immunohisto-and immunogold labeling we found that in addition to mitochondrial localization present in control and hypothyroid groups, strong MnSOD immunopositivity was also present in nuclei of early premeiotic germ cells after 7 and 15 days of treatment. Our results suggest a key role of MnSOD in protection of early spermatocytes against DNA damage in oxidative stress condition induced during establishing of hypothyroidism.

body_text.text: Obese diabetic pregnancy increases in utero oxidative stress and the risk of long-term cardiometabolic dysfunction to both mother and child. Similar findings are reported in murine obese pregnancy. We sought to assess whether activation of the antioxidant transcriptional regulator Nrf2 could improve maternal and fetal outcomes during pregnancy. Proven breeder wild-type dams were fed a normal chow (lean) or obesogenic diet (Ob) for 6 weeks before mating, with and without daily sulforaphane (SFN 0.5-5mg/kg) supplementation during pregnancy. Maternal weight was monitored through-out and pregnancy outcomes studied at termination on gestational day 17.5. Ob pregnancy reduced gestational weight gain (meanAES.E.M Ob 1.47AE0.09 vs Lean 1.75AE0.06g/pup), which was dose-dependently restored by SFN supplementation. Ob dams showed trends for a higher frequency of miscarriage, fetal resorption and a reduced litter size, all of which were ameliorated by SFN administration. Ob pregnancy reduced fetal weight (Ob 0.71AE0.02g vs Lean 0.91AE0.02g), with SFN supplementation causing a dose-dependent increase in fetal weight and restoration of the placental:fetal weight ratio to that of lean dams (Ob 0.13AE0.01 vs Lean 0.1AE0.01). Our preliminary findings suggest that SFN, administered within the normal dietary range, is not only safe but improves maternal and fetal outcomes associated with obese diabetic pregnancy.

We aimed to determine the potential role of GSTO1 and GSTO2 polymorphisms as determinants of postoperative prognosis in patients with the most aggressive renal cell carcinoma subtype (ccRCC). Furthermore, we assessed phosphorylation status of PI3K/PTEN/Akt/mTOR and Raf/ MEK/ERK signaling pathways in non-tumor and tumor ccRCC tissue, as well as possible association of GSTO1-1 with signaling molecules known to be regulated by glutathionylation. GSTO1 (rs4925) and GSTO2 (rs156697 and rs2297235) genotyping was performed in 239 ccRCC patients, while ccRCC tissue and non-tumor specimens were used for immunoprecipitation and immunoblot. In the multivariate Cox regression analysis ccRCC patients' carriers of GSTO1*CC (rs4925) genotype had significantly increased hazard ratio compared to the carriers of GSTO1*A allele (p¼0.05). Expression of phosphorylated proteins of Akt/MAPK signaling pathway (RSK1p90 (pS380), Akt (pS473) and ERK1/2 (pY204/187)) was increased in ccRCC tumor compared to corresponding non-tumor specimens. What is more, immunoprecipitation has shown an association of GSTO1-1 with Akt, phospho-Akt (Thr308), and ASK1. The possible molecular mechanism underlying the role of GSTO1-1 in ccRCC progression might be partially explained by its deglutathionylase activity.

Protein denitrosylation controls tumor progression, metabolism and aging The modification of protein cysteine residues by nitric oxide (NO), namely S-nitrosylation, is the prototypic redox modification of thiol groups affecting protein functions. Although the biology of NO has been extensively studied, the major efforts focus on NO biosynthesis while the role played by enzymes terminating the signal (denitrosylases) has been overlooked. S-nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR) is the main denitrosylating enzyme controlling the amount of S-nitrosylated proteins by reducing S-nitrosoglutathione (GSNO).

body_text.text: Here, we deal with the effects induced by GSNOR-deficiency, with a focus on alterations of mitochondria quality control and energetics. We provide evidence that, due to mitochondrial defects, GSNOR-deficient cancer cells are extremely sensitive to mitochondrial toxins. We further demonstrate that GSNOR declines during aging, and the resulting mitochondrial dysfunctions have profound impact on cell senescence and metabolic rewiring, both features commonly associated with cancer. In addition to the effects on mitochondria, we show that GSNOR suppression affects the adhesion properties of malignant cells promoting the epithelial-mesenchymal transition. Furthermore, GSNOR-deficiency induces anoikis resistance, a critical step driving metastasis. Altogether our results suggest that protein S-nitrosylation has a pivotal role in the aggressive phenotype of cancer cells affecting cell adhesion, anchoragedependent survival and metabolism adaptation.

Linkage of cytosolic antioxidant enzymes to the erythrocyte membrane as protection mechanism in hereditary spherocytosis Our aim was to evaluate the binding of cytosolic antioxidant enzymes to the erythrocyte membrane and its relationship with well-known oxidative stress biomarkers -membrane bound hemoglobin (MBH) and membrane lipid peroxidation (LPO) -in Hereditary Spherocytosis (HS) patients. We studied 74 HS patients, assessing MBH and LPO by spectrophotometry and the erythrocyte membrane bound amount of catalase (CAT), glutathione peroxidase (GPx) and peroxiredoxin 2 (Prx2), by westernblot. CAT, CATþGPx or CATþGPxþPrx2 were detected in 43, 7 and 24 HS patients, respectively. The total amount of the three enzymes linked to the membrane was strongly correlated with MBH (r ¼ 0.497, p<0.001) but not with LPO (r ¼ 0.156, p ¼ 0.183). We also evaluated the levels of MBH and LPO according to the quartiles of membrane bound enzymes amount and found that, while MBH significantly increased, LPO showed no changes between the different quartiles.

Oteiza Fisicoquímica, Facultad de Farmacia y Bioquímica, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Instituto de Bioquímica y Medicina Molecular (IBIMOL), Universidad de Buenos Aires-CONICET, Buenos Aires, Argentina Supplementation with anthocyanidins (AC), i.e. cyanidin and delphinidin, caused a decrease in body weight gain and fat deposits in mice fed a high fat diet (HF). This study investigated the capacity of dietary AC to promote "beiging" of subcutaneous white adipose tissue (sWAT), through increased mitochondrial biogenesis and thermogenesis. C57BL/ 6J male mice were fed control (C) or HF diets, with or without supplementation with 40 mg AC/kg body weight (CA and HFA). After 15 w, HF consumption caused obesity and increased eWAT weight, which were mitigated by AC supplementation. Adipocyte diameter was higher in HF than in C, CA and HFA mice. H&E stain showed images compatible with beiging in both AC-treated groups. Electron microscopy (TEM) showed a fewer number of mitochondria in HF but not in HFA mice. TEM findings were confirmed by measuring the expression of mitochondrial protein markers. AC prevented HF-induced inhibition of the pathway leading to mitochondria biogenesis (PPARγ, PRDM16, PGC-1α), and thermogenic respiration (UCP-1). Mice consuming the control diet plus AC also showed upregulation of PPARγ, PRDM16, PGC-1α. Findings suggest that consumption of selct AC could be an important strategy to mitigate HFinduced obesity in part via activation of adipocyte mitochondriogenesis and beiging. Oxygen and iron are essential for many fundamental processes of life including DNA and ATP synthesis. Nevertheless, dysregulated oxygen and iron can result in excessive formation of oxygen radicals that can cause tissue injury and death. Therefore, cellular oxygen and iron metabolism should be tightly regulated at all times. However, how this is achieved at the whole animal level is still mysterious. Here, we explore this question using the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. We found that the conserved iron-cage protein ferritin 1 (ftn-1) is differentially expressed in the intestine during hypoxia and reoxygenation stress. Intriguingly, we show that ftn-1 expression is controlled by oxygen -sensory neuron signalling. Furthermore, our data suggest that hydroxylated HIF-1 inhibits ftn-1 expression, while non-hydroxylated HIF-1 has no function in ftn-1 regulation. Finally, we demonstrate that ftn-1 upregulation in hypoxia protects against Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteria. Together, our studies provide novel insights into the way oxygen and iron responses are regulated at both the cellular and whole animal level. In the past decades obesity and the associated development of type 2 diabetes (T2D) became major public health concerns worldwide. β-cell apoptosis is central to the pathophysiology of T2D. Oxidative and endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress, both associated with consumption of Western-style diets and obesity, underlie β-cell apoptosis. We previously showed that the flavan-3-ol (-)-epicatechin (EC) improves insulin sensitivity in part by mitigating oxidative and ER stress in the liver and adipose tissue from mice fed a high fat (HF) diet. This study investigated both in vivo (HF-fed mice) and in vitro (INS-1 cells) if EC can mitigate fatinduced oxidative/ER tress and the consequent β-cell apoptosis. In vivo, EC supplementation prevented HF-associated pancreatic trygliceride deposition, enlargement of islets, and ER/oxidative stress. In INS-1 β-cells, palmitate (1mM) caused ER stress (activation of the three UPR branches: ATF6, IRE1α and PERK). It also caused increased expression of NOX1 and NOX4, protein carbonylation, and activation of the redoxsensitive NF-κB pathway. INS-1 cell apoptosis was evidenced by caspase 3 activation. EC (0.5-1 μM) mitigated or prevented all the adverse effects of palmitate in INS-1 cells. In summary, consumption of EC-rich diets, together with an improved lifestyle, can mitigate obesity associated β-cell dysfunction and T2D progression. Bacterial keratitis is a major cause of visual impairment and blindness globally. Streptococcus pneumoniae, a Gram-positive invasive pathogen, is one of the leading causes of keratitis in India and worldwide. Because corneal infections due to S. pneumoniae are very aggressive irrespective of antibiotic sensitivity, we sought to investigate the host response with emphasis on antioxidant signaling. We determined the presence of oxidative stress in S. pneumonia infected corneal tissues removed during penetrating keratoplasty which indicates oxidative stress to play a role in pathogenesis of corneal infections. However, the task of NRF2 and antioxidant signaling in case of S. pneumonia keratitis is not well studied. Using our in vitro model of infection, we saw that S. pneumoniae generates reactive oxygen species in human corneal epithelial cells and impedes NRF2 activation. It also causes down regulation of expression of antioxidant genes like HO-1, and NQO1. Further, we found that S. pneumoniae induces Akt activation and inhibits autophagy in these cells. Using a known NRF2 inducer, tBHQ, oxidative stress was reduced and helped to restore autophagy in S. pneumonia infected cells in a NRF2 dependant manner. Thus, there is a prospect of treating S. pneumonia infections by exploiting its antioxidant signaling pathways. The aim was to study the early events that take place in heart mitochondrial dysfunction in a Type 1 DM model, in which hyperglycemia happens without the presence of insulin resistance, obesity, hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. Diabetes was induced by Streptozotocin (1 dose,60 mg/kg,ip.) in male rats (glycemia, C:130AE5, DM:413AE26 mg/ dl). Animals were sacrificed at day 10. The state 3 O consumption sustained by malate-glutamate (22%) and the respiratory control (39%) were lower in heart from DM animals, in accordance with the reduction in complex I-III activity (19%) . No differences in O 2 uptake sustained by succinate and in complexes II-III or IV activities were observed. H O 2 (96%) and NO (25%) production rates, and NOS expression (79%) were higher in DM group. Mitochondrial [GSSGþGSH] was lower in DM rats, but there was no difference in GSH/GSSG ratio. PGC-1α expression was similar in both groups, suggesting that mitochondrial biogenesis has not been triggered yet. After 7 days of hyperglycemia, heart mitochondrial dysfunction was observed, with complex I being the only complex modified. Linear correlations between the modified mitochondrial parameters and glycemia were obtained. H 2 O 2 and NO could be upstream molecules to de novo synthesis of mitochondria in response to hyperglycemia. Chemiluminescence is phenomena that occurs when a significant fraction of the exothermicity of a chemical reaction is transformed into electronic excitation energy of reaction product, which they can emit a photon light. Chemiluminescence can be split up into a chemiexcitation and luminescence step. photon emission from the intermediate process is a well-known as luminescence step which serves to announce the presence of an electronically excited state. in this study, we focus on the electronically excited state species. specially triplet carbonyl group by using a machine learning approach. This paper, shade a new light on the notion that metabolism and oxidative reactions are underlying processes which generate endogenous biological chemiluminescence. in the light of recent findings, one can contribute a novel method for non-invasive and label-free sensing of oxidative processes in biology. It is universally recognized that ROS hyperproduction with subsequent activation of the processes leading to formation of lipid oxidation products is a characteristic feature of oxidative stress. We have shown that besides oxidation ROS induce fragmentation of hydroxyl-containing lipids, such as lyso-phosphatidyl choline (lyso-PC) and cardiolipin, involving their polar component. Such processes occur without participation of oxygen and result in formation of new lipid moleculespalmitoxyacetone (PA) and phosphatidylhydroxyacetone (PHA), respectively. The mechanism of free-radical decomposition of lyso-PC includes the stage of formation of α-hydroxyl-containing carbon-centered radicals from the original lipid, followed by fragmentation with rate constants of the order of 107 s-1. Therefore, oxygen cannot inhibit reactions of this type at its physiological concentrations. Biological properties of PA and PHA have not been studied thus far. Using isolated rat liver mitochondria, we have shown that PA and PHA noticeably inhibited Ca 2þ -stimulated processes of mitochondrial membrane permeability transition while increasing the rate of Ca 2þ -induced membrane depolarization. Being negatively charged and more hydrophobic, PHA manifested more pronounced effects. The effects of PH and PHA might be related to their ionophoric properties.

body_text.text: 157. Role of advanced glycation end products, interleukin-6 and bone morphogenetic protein-2 on aortic calcification in diabetes type 2: a cross-sectional study Vascular calcification is a highly prevalent disease in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2DM) as compared to the non-diabetic population. However, its pathogenesis is not fully understood. Recent evidences suggest that calcification in T2DM is an active, cell-mediated process in which hyperglycemia, bone and inflammatory markers are involved in its initiation and progression. This led us to perform a cross-sectional study to investigate the relation of circulating advanced glycation end products (AGEs), interleukin-6 (IL-6) and bone morphogenetic protein-2 (BMP-2) levels on aortic abdominal calcification (AAC) in patients with T2DM (n ¼ 104). All subjects were given lateral lumbar X-rays in order to quantify AAC (score 0-24 point) and the concentrations of AGEs, BMP-2 and IL-6 were determined in blood samples. Our results indicate that subjects with higher AAC score have higher levels of circulating AGEs (r¼0.784, p<0.001), BMP-2 (r¼0.579, p<0.001) and IL-6 (r¼0.388, p<0.001), indicating that these compounds act actively in calcification process and posing AGEs as potential inducers. These data suggest that vascular calcification in T2DM is a multifactorial process in which hyperglycemia, inflammatory and immunological events play a central role in its initiation and progression.

body_text.text: 158. Mitochondrially-targeted deferoxamine induces mitophagy and acts as anti-cancer agent in vivo C. Sandoval-Acuña 1 , N. Torrealba , V. Tomkova , K. Blazkova , J. Neuzil 1,2 , J. Stursa , L. Werner , and J. Truksa Iron is a crucial nutrient for proliferating cancer cells. Thus, we have synthesized a mitochondrially targeted derivative of the iron chelator deferoxamine (mDFO) and evaluated its ability to selectively eliminate cancer cells both in vitro and in vivo. Viability of human cancer cells treated with mDFO was assessed by crystal violet or annexin V staining. ROS production was assessed through fluorescent probes MitoSOX and DCF. Blue native electrophoresis and Seahorse were used to analyse mitochondrial function. The in vivo effect of mDFO was assessed by xenografting triple negative breast cancer cells in NOD/ Scid mice. Our results show that mDFO is at least 100-fold more efficient than DFO in killing cancer cells. In addition, mDFO was shown to reduce respiration and dramatically decrease the amount and composition of mitochondrial respiratory supercomplexes. Both the latter effects might trigger the observed increase in mitochondrial superoxide production, the fragmentation of mitochondria and the activation of mitophagy. Importantly, in vivo results show that mDFO is effective in slowing the tumour growth. mDFO represents an effective drug to inhibit tumour growth in vivo and might represent the lead compound in a new generation of anti-cancer agents based on mitochondrial iron chelation.

body_text.text: 159. SIRT1-dependent response is crucial for the resveratrolinduced upregulation of antioxidant and antiglycative defence in high glucose-challenged HUVECs Oxidative stress and glycative stress are thought to be strictly involved in the endothelial dysfunction that precedes diabetes-related vascular complications. Hence, researchers are increasingly interested in enhancing antioxidative and antiglycative protection in high glucose (HG)-challenged endothelium. Resveratrol (RSV), a natural phytoalexin, improves endothelial function upon HG, however it remains to be established whether RSV protects HG-challenged endothelial cells mostly via direct antioxidant effects or by modulating the major antioxidative/ antiglycative defence systems. More importantly, it remains to be demonstrated whether RSV-dependent effects require SIRT1, a NAD þdependent deac(et)ylase critically involved in metabolic adaptation, DNA repair, cell survival and response to oxidative/glycative stress. In this work, we treated human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) with HG (30.6 mM) for 24 h, with or without RSV or RSVþEX527 (SIRT 1 inhibitor). Cytotoxicity, stress response-related changes in membrane dynamics, and expression/activity of SIRT1, as well as of the major reactive oxygen species (ROS)-and methylglyoxal (MG)-targeting detoxification systems were assessed. We found that the strong cytoprotective effect elicited by RSV in HGchallenged HUVECs strictly depends on SIRT1. Moreover, our results suggest that RSV protects HUVECs from HG cytotoxicity mostly by upregulating one of the major antiglycative defence (i.e., glyoxalase 1).

body_text.text: Institute for Drug Research, Faculty of Medicine, The Hebrew University, Jerusalem, Israel Chronic hyperglycaemia in diabetes induces vascular endothelial cell (VEC) dysfunction and atherosclerotic lesions. We discovered inherent and adaptive protective mechanisms in VEC in diabetes: VEC, whose basal glucose transport capacity is significantly lower than in vascular smooth muscle cells, are less susceptible to glucose-dependent metabolic insults. Furthermore, high levels of glucose induce downregulation of glucose transport by increasing the expression of the protein calreticulin, which renders Glucose Transporter-1 (GLUT1) mRNA highly sensitive to nuclease degradation, and therefore reduces GLUT1 expression, and thus limits glucose influx. Nonetheless, prolonged and unresolved hyperglycaemic periods accelerate phospholipid remodelling and the release of polyunsaturated fatty acids (e.g., arachidonic and linoleic acids) intracellularly. These are transformed non-enzymatically by glucose-derived free radicals into 4-hydroxyalkenals (e.g., 4-HNE, 4-HDDE). We discovered that these aldehydes interact with PPARδ to induce the expression of the pro-oxidant thioredoxin-interacting protein (TXNIP). The latter initiates and propagates wide-spread senescence in VEC. Immunohistochemical examinations of human carotid plaques have identified such senescent VEC on the cap surface. It is concluded that VEC tolerate well short-term hyperglycaemic excursions by the inherent autoregulation of glucose transport. However, chronic hyperglycaemia and oxidative environment induce cell senescence that often leads to cell demise and enhances atherogenesis.

body_text.text: 161. GSTP1*G/GSTP1*T and GSTO1*A/GSTO2*G haplotypes affect the prostate cancer risk Ana Savic-Radojevic 1,3 , Veljko Santric 2,3 , Sonja Suvakov 1,3 , Milica Djokic 1 , Dejan Dragicevic 2,3 , Marija Pljesa-Ercegovac 1,3 , Marija Matic 1,3 , Tatjana Simic 1, 3 Institute of Medical and Clinical Biochemistry, Belgrade, Serbia 2 Clinic of Urology, Clinical Center of Serbia, Belgrade, Serbia Faculty of Medicine, Belgrade University, Serbia Aberrant methylation of glutathione transferase P1 (mGSTP1) is the most common genetic alteration so far reported in prostate cancer (PC). Moreover, the presence of mGSTP1 in the circulation is associated with tumor aggressiveness. It seems that polymorphisms in GSTs could also contribute to PC occurrence and progression, affecting both the proliferation capacity of tumor cells and response to therapy. In this study we evaluated the modifying effect of six specific GST gene variants (GSTM1, GSTT1, GSTP1*A313G rs1695, GSTP1*C341T rs1138272, GSTO1*C419A rs4925, GSTO2*A424G rs156697), independently and in interaction with established risk factors on the PC risk. Genotyping was performed in 219 PC patients and 187 age-matched controls. As a result, GSTT1-null (OR¼1.69, p¼0.038), as well as all three variant GSTO2*G/G (OR¼3.2, p¼0.009), GSTP1*G/G (OR¼2.45, p¼0.012) and GSTP1*T/T (OR¼5.62, p¼0.036) exhibited increased risk of PC development. Additionally, association observed for combined variant GSTP1 and GSTO genotypes was confirmed at the haplotype level (GSTP1*G/ GSTP1*T, p¼0.032 and GSTO1*A/GSTO2*G haplotype, p<0.001), suggesting a potential role of those variants in susceptibility to PC. In conclusion, the concomitance of GSTs polymorphisms may influence PC risk.
body_text.section: Shlomo Sasson

body_text.text: Valeria Scalcon 1 , Alessandra Folda , Federica Tonolo , Alberto Bindoli , Arne Holmgren , Maria Pia Rigobello , Lucia Coppo The mouse strain lacking Grx2 specifically in the mitochondrial compartment [1], herein called mGD, did not show major alterations compared to wild-type (WT) mice, in the overall mitochondrial redox homeostasis in different organs withdrawn from three months-old mice. Mitochondria isolated from the liver, kidney, brain and heart were subjected to the determination of total thiols, glutathione content and enzymatic activities of TrxR2 and GR and no significant differences were observed between WT and mGD animals. However, mGD liver displayed lipid deposits and liver mitochondria showed an increased ROS production, impaired oxygen consumption capacity, decreased mitochondrial membrane potential and a higher sensitivity to calcium in the swelling assay. Interestingly, mGD liver mitochondria presented also an altered morphology. In fact, TEM analysis of liver tissue and isolated organelles showed "donut-shaped" mitochondria. Altogether, these preliminary results indicate that the lack of Grx2 in the mitochondrial compartment is responsible for the development of an early-onset fatty liver in which a decrease of mitochondrial activity associated to an increased sensitivity to calcium is involved.

body_text.text: [1] Branco, V. et al. Impaired cross-talk between the thioredoxin and glutathione systems is related to ASK-1 mediated apoptosis in neuronal cells exposed to mercury. Redox Biol. 13, (2017). The aim of this research is to assess lipid peroxidation and antioxidant protection system parameters in Caucasian menopausal women depending on the glutathione S-transferase M1 genotype. 224 Caucasian menopausal women divided into 2 groups (with non-functional (n¼95) and functional (n¼129) glutathione S-transferase M1 genotypes) were examined. DNA genotyping was carried out by the polymerase chain reaction method. Lipid peroxidation (conjugated dienes, thiobarbituric acid reactants) and antioxidant defense system parameters (α-tocopherol, retinol, reduced and oxidized glutathione, and total antioxidant activity, activities of the superoxide dismutase, glutathione peroxidase, and glutathione S-transferase and glutathione reductase) were determined by spectrofluorofotometer methods. Statistical analysis was performed by parametric tests with p<0.05 as the level of significance. It was shown that conjugated dienes (1.45 times; p<0.05), thiobarbituric acid reactants (1.29 times; p<0.05), retinol (1.29 times; p<0.05) levels, total antioxidant activity (1.24 times; p<0.05) are higher in women with functional glutathione S-transferase M1 genotype compared to group with non-functional glutathione S-transferase M1 genotype. Moreover, glutathione peroxidase activity is lower (1.44 times; p<0.05) in women with functional glutathione S-transferase M1 genotype. Lipid peroxidation processes and antioxidant system are more active in Caucasian menopausal women with functional glutathione S-transferase M1 genotype. The aim of this research is to assess antioxidant system activity in Asian menopausal women depending on the glutathione S-transferase M1 (GSTM1) and T1 (GSTT1) genotypes. 189 Asian menopausal women were examined. Exclusion criteria: exacerbation of chronic diseases; hormone replacement therapy; surgical menopause; the use of pills. DNA genotyping was carried out by the polymerase chain reaction method. Antioxidant defense system parameters (α-tocopherol, retinol, reduced and oxidized glutathione, total antioxidant activity, activities of the superoxide dismutase, glutathione peroxidase, glutathione S-transferase and glutathione reductase) were determined by spectrofluorofotometer methods. Statistical analysis was performed by parametric tests with p<0.05 as the level of significance. It was shown that glutathione peroxidase (1.29 times; p<0.05) and glutathione reductase (1.31 times; p<0.05) activities are lower in Asian women with functional GSTM1 genotype compared to group with non-functional GSTM1 genotype. Also, it was found that total antioxidant activity (1.32 times; p<0.05) and glutathione S-transferase activity (1.44 times; p<0.05) are lower in women with non-functional GSTT1 genotype compared to group with functional GSTT1 one. Functional GSTM1 and non-functional GSTT1 genotypes in Asian menopausal women are associated with lower antioxidant system activity.
