body_text.text: 165. Nanostructured lipid dispersions for topical administration of antioxidants 169. Paving the way for intracellular detection of free radicals with nanodiamond magnetometry Alina Sigaeva, Felipe Perona Martinez, Anggrek Citra Nusantara, Nikos Mougios, Romana Schirhagl Department of Biomedical Engineering, University Medical Center Groningen, University of Groningen, Groningen, The Netherlands Free radical formation plays an extremely important role in normal cellular functions, as well as development of various pathological conditions. While more detailed information on the free radical production could give us new insights into these processes, it is generally hard to directly detect free radicals due to their highly reactive nature. Most common methods for free radical detection are not very sensitive and selective enough. They usually provide general information on the cell status, while the spatiotemporal distribution of free radical production is largely lost. Most importantly, these approaches rely on the reaction between the probe and the radicals, so they might be interfering with free radical signaling. Fluorescent nanodiamonds (FNDs) can act as nanoscale probes for magnetic properties of their environment. In this study, we trigger free radical production in mammalian cells with internalized FNDs and attempt to detect these elusive molecules by their effect on spin-lattice relaxation of nitrogen-vacancy defects of the diamond crystal structure. We compare this approach to the conventional methods for the assessment of oxidative stress and free radical production in cells. Our study serves as the first proof of concept for this novel application of FNDs as free radical detectors in live cells.

body_text.text: Adam Sikora, Jan Adamus, Jakub Pięta, Radosław Michalski Institute of Applied Radiation Chemistry, Lodz University of Technology, Lodz, Poland Nitric oxide ( NO) and hydrogen sulfide (H 2 S) are recognized as biological messengers involved in cellular signaling through formation of several important protein modifications, such as protein S-nitrosothiols, disulfides and persulfides. It is postulated that simultaneous production of these two gasotransmitters leads to the formation of HNO, SNO À , SSNO À and polysulfides, resulting in the formation of complex reaction network with significant role in cellular signaling. Here we report, that the generation of nitric oxide in aqueous solutions of HS À anions under aerobic conditions at physiological pH leads to the formation of peroxynitrite as a major reactive intermediate. We have detected and quantified ONOO À in aqueous solutions of HS À and NO donor (PAPA-NONOate) with the aid of boronate probes [e.g. coumarin-7-boronic acid (CBA) and boronate derivative of resorufin (PC1)]. The results of our study show that peroxynitrite is formed in H 2 S/ NO/O 2 system with the high yieldwe obtained the stoichiometry of 1 mol of peroxynitrite formed per 2 mol of generated nitric oxide. For better description of complex reaction network of NO/H 2 S crosstalk we have performed computer-assisted kinetic simulations. Oxidative stress response via Nrf2-mediated pathway serves as the hub between inflammation-and metabolism-related pathways in end stage renal disease (ESRD). We assessed the association of polymorphisms in Nrf2, superoxide dismutase (SOD2) and glutathione peroxidase (GPX1) genes with the risk of ESRD, and their functional significance in ESRD patients. These polymorphisms have also been evaluated, with GSTM1 deletion polymorphism, in panel designed to predict ESRD prognosis. Polymorphisms in Nrf2 (rs6721961), SOD2 (rs4880), GPX1 (rs1050450) and GSTM1 were determined by PCR in 256 ESRD patients and 374 controls. Eight biomarkers of oxidative distress were analysed spectrophotometricaly or by ELISA. Time to event modeling was performed in evaluation of survival. SOD2(Val/Val) genotype increased ESRD risk, which was even higher in carriers of combined SOD2(Val/Val)/GPX1(Leu/Leu) genotypes. Polymorphism in SOD2 showed an effect on oxidative distress. Overall survival in ESRD patients was dependent on the combination of the Nrf2(C/C) and GPX1(Leu/Leu) genotypes in addition to age and GSTM1 polymorphism. Obtained results might be relevant since significant associations between patients' age, antioxidant enzyme polymorphisms and survival were found. Our results support multimarker strategy in evaluation of ESRD patients' prognosis, which includes specific combination of biomarkers that reflect oxidative distress underlying ESRD and its complications. King's British Heart Foundation Centre of Research Excellence, School of Cardiovascular Medicine and Sciences, King's College London, UK Cytosolic labile iron pool (LIP) is normally held low to protect the cell from oxidative stress. As lysosomal proteases and iron acutely increase after UVA exposure and protease inhibitors reduce leakage of lysosomal contents and apoptosis, lysosomes are inferred to be the primary source of increased LIP. However, until now, the time resolution required to accurately assess whether lysosomal damage is a primary or secondary response to iron release was insufficient.
body_text.section: Peroxynitrite is an important reactive intermediate formed in the reactions between nitric oxide, hydrogen sulfide and molecular oxygen

body_text.text: We have used a fluorescence probe (FeRhoNox-1) specific for ferrous ion to monitor intracellular LIP changes in human dermal fibroblasts and dermal endothelial cells following exposure to UVA, incubated with low concentrations of zinc, known to block iron diffusion via ferritin threefold channels. The fibroblast iron signal immediately increased by approximately 100% after 8 kJ/m 2 UVA (360 nm) irradiation (P<0.001), whilst 10 and 40 μM ZnSO 4 prevented this UVA-dependent increase (P<0.001). The UVA response was exacerbated by superoxide dismutase (SOD) inhibitor, ammonium tetrathiomolybdate 4μM, implicating superoxide-enhanced ferritin iron release in the UVA-response. These results suggest that the UVA-dependent increase in skin fibroblast LIP is sourced primarily from ferritin iron and the subsequent oxidative stress may exacerbate the dermal cell ageing phenotype. NRF-2 is a transcription factor well known to provide an advantage for cancer growth and survival regulating the cellular redox pathway. In breast cancer cells, we identified the heme-globin Neuroglobin (NGB) as part of a new mechanism induced by 17β-estradiol (E2) against oxidative stress. While there is mounting evidence suggesting a critical role of NGB as a sensor of oxidative stress, little is known about its involvement in NRF-2 pathway activation in breast cancer cells. In this study, we identify a new role for NGB in the cell response to oxidative stress. Although NGB is not involved in the rapid E2-induced NRF-2 stability, E2 loses the capacity to regulate the expression of NRF-2 dependent genes in NGBdepleted MCF-7 cells. These data sustain a role of NGB as a compensatory protein in the E2-activated pathway devoted to increase cancer cells tolerance to ROS generation in stressing conditions acting as key regulator of NRF-2 pathway activity in a time dependent manner. Pyruvate kinase catalyses the last step in glycolysis and may contribute to regulation of aerobic glycolysis in cancer cells, where there is a more prooxidant state. This state also favours lipid peroxidation and the formation of electrophilic fragmentation products, including short-chain aldehydes e.g. 4-hydroxy-2-hexenal (HHE), malondialdehyde and acrolein. As little is known about the interaction of these molecules with pyruvate kinase, we investigated their reactions with and effects on the activity of the enzyme. Analysis by LC-MSMS showed unique modification profiles for each aldehyde, with only Lys 393 and 475 modified by all 3 compounds. Acrolein was the most potent inhibitor, and at incubation times of 2 hours or more, pathophysiological concentrations (2-10 μM) induced significant effects. Treatment of MCF-7 cells caused similar losses of activity to treatment in vitro. Cys326, Cys358, and Cys474 were found to be modified in acrolein-treated pyruvate kinase, and as they are conserved residues located at or near the allosteric or active sites of the pyruvate kinase isoforms, they may contribute to loss of activity. These results suggest that reactive short-chain aldehydes generated during inflammatory diseases or environmental exposure could be involved in metabolic changes observed in cancer cells through alteration of pyruvate kinase activity.
body_text.section: Modulation of oxi-inflammation during ageing by quercetinquinone derivative

body_text.text: 176. Oxysterol brain levels and Alzheimer's disease: the impact on astrocyte reactivity and neuronal health Evidence indicates that cholesterol oxidation products, named oxysterols, contribute to Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathogenesis through various mechanisms. In this regard, we recently demonstrated that several oxysterols progressively accumulate in AD brain as disease worsens. Astrocytes support neuronal functioning in many ways; evidence suggests that astrocyte reactivity is involved in AD pathogenesis since astrocytic inflammatory pathways are important mediators of changes in tau and synapse health. Yet the outcome of astrocyte activation is not completely clear. Two oxysterol mixtures were used, whose composition was based on our previous oxysterol quantification in mild (early AD) and severe AD (late AD) brain samples. Mouse derived primary cortical astrocytes and neurons were used as in vitro models. Preliminary results showed that both the oxysterol mixtures modulate astrocyte reactivity inducing the synthesis of Lipocalin-2 and SerpinA3N, both proteins identified as new potential reactive astrocyte markers. Alongside the increase in Lipocalin-2 and SerpinA3N synthesis, astrocytes showed a clear morphological change indicative of reactivity. Coculture experiments showed a significant reduction of the post-synaptic marker PSD95 protein levels and a concurrent increase of cleaved caspase-3 protein levels in neurons, suggesting that oxysterols could also indirectly affect neuronal health acting on astrocytes.

body_text.text: 177. Induction of selenium-binding protein 1 (SELENBP1) in the course of differentiation and maturation of adipocytes and H 2 S may augment adipocyte differentiation and lipid accumulation. We found that SELENBP1 is induced when 3T3-L1 preadipocytes undergo terminal differentiation and maturation to adipocytes. SELENBP1 induction succeeded the up-regulation of known marker proteins of white adipocytes and the intracellular accumulation of lipids. Immunofluorescence microscopy revealed predominant cytoplasmic localisation of SELENBP1 in adipocytes. In differentiating 3T3-L1 cells, the mTOR inhibitor rapamycin and the pro-inflammatory cytokine tumour necrosis factor alpha likewise suppressed SELENBP1 induction, adipocyte differentiation and lipid accumulation. However, lipid accumulation per se is not linked to SELENBP1 induction, as hepatic SELENBP1 was down-regulated in high fructose-fed mice despite increased lipogenesis in the liver and development of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). Thus, SELENBP1 is a marker of cell differentiation/maturation rather than being linked to lipogenesis/lipid accumulation. As studies in tumour cells suggest that SELENBP1 counteracts proliferation and dedifferentiation, SELENBP1 may support the maintenance of a well-differentiated phenotype in mature adipocytes.
body_text.section: Modulation of oxi-inflammation during ageing by quercetinquinone derivative

body_text.text: 178.Lysosomal cystine depleting agent, cysteamine, improves redox status and mitochondrial function but does not correct Na þ ,K þ -ATPase and metabolic dysfunction in CTNS null renal proximal tubular cells Cysteamine is employed as a cystine-depleting therapy for cystinosis, a rare lysosomal cystine storage disorder caused by various mutations in the CTNS gene. Cysteamine has been shown to retard renal complications in cystinosis patients but it does not treat the renal tubulopathy associated with the disease. In this study, the effects of cysteamine on redox status, expression of redox-sensitive genes, nutrient metabolism, and Na þ ,K þ -ATPase activity were investigated in CTNS null renal proximal tubular cells (RPTCs). Cysteamine markedly increased the GSH/GSSG ratio in CTNS null RPTCs, accompanied by a reduction in the levels of intracellular ROS. The expression of the redox-sensitive genes, NRF-2, HSF-1, and HSP70, was restored to normal levels following treatment with cysteamine. Cysteamine enhanced the mitochondrial transmembrane potential and intracellular ATP production. Conversely, cysteamine did not improve the Na þ ,K þ -ATPase activity. Glucose and glutamine metabolism were also unaffected in the presence of cysteamine. The results indicate that cysteamine can improve the antioxidant capacity and mitochondrial function in RPTCs with CTNS gene deletion. However, lysosomal cystine accumulation alone may not be obligatory for the manifestation of some biochemical alterations in cystinosis. This may partly explain the persistence of renal Fanconi syndrome in cystinosis patients despite strict adherence to cysteamine therapy.
body_text.section: Modulation of oxi-inflammation during ageing by quercetinquinone derivative

body_text.text: 179. Antioxidant transcription factor Nrf2 and the circadian molecular clock interact in a tissue-specific, bi-directional manner NRF2 is the master mediator of protective antioxidant responses in many tissues. Disruption of NRF2 pathway is linked to many diseases associated with oxidative stress. Research from our lab identified Nrf2 as a clock-controlled gene, which leads to daily oscillations in NRF2 activation on target gene promoters. However, it is not known what impact Nrf2 pathway has upon molecular clock in different tissues in vivo. We investigated clock gene expression in Nrf2 KO mice over 24hrs in peripheral tissues. Nrf2 KO mice show tissue-specific changes in select clock gene loops and shorter periodicity in wheel-running behaviour. This was consistent with real-time bioluminescence imaging of Nrf2 KO/ Per2::luc reporter mice which showed altered rhythmicity of peripheral tissues. Loss-and gain-of-function experiments in human cells revealed acute effects of Nrf2 modulation on clock genes. Cell-autonomous changes in clock gene rhythms were recapitulated in primary MEFs from Nrf2 KO mice. Pharmacological intervention using Nrf2 activators led to significant changes in clock genes in a time-of-day manner in vivo. These results demonstrate tissue-specific, bi-directional regulation between NRF2 and the molecular clock. These novel findings suggest that altered circadian clock as a result of NRF2 dysregulation may contribute to tissue deterioration in ageing and chronic diseases.
body_text.section: Modulation of oxi-inflammation during ageing by quercetinquinone derivative

body_text.text: Toshinori Suzuki, Yuki Kishida School of Pharmacy, Shujitsu University, Okayama, Japan
body_text.section: Reaction of thymidine with ascorbic acid induced by UV in the presence of salicylic acid

body_text.text: Ascorbic acid is an important compound for antioxidant protection against UV-induced photodamage, since it can promote the differentiation of keratinocytes and decrease melanin synthesis. Many cosmetics include the sodium salt of ascorbic acid as an antioxidant at concentrations up to 0.3%. Recently we have shown that salicylic acid is a photosensitizer for thymidine dimers formation induced by UV. Many cosmetic products such as solution serums for skin care include salicylic acid as an ingredient for peeling at relatively high concentrations up to 3%. When a neutral solution of thymidine and ascorbic acid was irradiated with UV light having wavelength longer than 300 nm in the presence of salicylic acid as a photosensitizer, six product peaks appeared in a HPLC chromatogram in addition to small amounts of thymidine dimers. The products were isolated by HPLC and subjected to MS and NMR. The six products were identified as three pairs of diastereomers of two ascorbyl adducts of thymidine (novel compounds) and 5,6-dihydrothymidine. The results suggest that novel DNA damages may generate by ascorbic acid with salicylic acid induced by sunlight.
body_text.section: Reaction of thymidine with ascorbic acid induced by UV in the presence of salicylic acid

body_text.text: 181. The chalcone cardamonin activates Nrf2 in HepG2 human hepatoma cells independent of the cellular selenium status Many secondary plant metabolites as well as the micronutrient selenium (Se) are thought to be beneficial for human health, such as for prevention of oxidative stress-related disorders. In this regard, the chalcone cardamonin has recently been identified as inducer of Nrf2-regulated antioxidant enzymes, two of them being selenoenzymes. We investigated a potential interplay between the cellular selenium (Se) status and the Nrf2 signaling pathway, using HepG2 cells cultured under Se-deficient, Se-adequate and Se-supranutritional conditions. Expression of selected Nrf2 target genes was measured by qRTPCR and immunoblotting. Cellular Nrf2 localization was detected by immunoblotting after cytoplasmic/nuclear fractionation. Sulforaphane (SFN), a well-known plant-derived Nrf2-activator, and diethyl maleate (DEM), a thiolmodulating chemical, served as controls. Treatment with the three substances resulted in rapid induction of Nrf2 and its enrichment in the nucleus, independent of the cellular Se status. All three compounds caused an up-regulation of Nrf2 target genes, although with differences regarding extent and time course of their induction. The most pronounced induction of the selected Nrf2 target genes, with up to 20-fold increase in gene expression, was observed for HMOX1/HO-1. The Se status did not significantly affect gene or protein expression of the Nrf2 target genes.

body_text.text: Adult health is affected by neonatal Parenteral Nutrition (PN). Oxidative stress is suspected. Peroxide contamination, ascorbate and cysteine deficiencies could be the main culprits. We investigated the short-and longterm impacts of neonatal PN (þ/-glutathione -as in vivo antiperoxide) and ascorbate or cysteine deficient diets over lung glutathione.
body_text.section: Reaction of thymidine with ascorbic acid induced by UV in the presence of salicylic acid

body_text.text: Methods: Three-day-old guinea pigs received: 1) PN; 2) PNþglutathione (6-12μM); 3) Ascorbate-deficient diet; 4) Cysteine-deficient diet; 5) Complete diets (Controls). Animals were sacrificed after 4 days (neonatal age) or at adulthood. Results: Neonatal lung GSH was decreased in both deficient (Def), and both PN groups (Def:45AE2; PNþ/-glutathione:31AE2; Controls:52AE4 nmol/prot; p 0.05). The contrary was observed at adulthood (Def:49AE1; PN:50AE2; Controls:41AE2 nmol/prot; p 0.05). Neonatal lung GSSG was decreased in PNþglutathione (PNþglutathione:0.3AE0.1; PN:0.6AE0.1; Controls:0.9AE0.2 nmol/prot; p 0.05).

body_text.text: The pattern was inversed at long term (PNþglutathione:2.5AE0.4; PN:1.2AE0.2; Controls:1.8AE0.6 nmol/prot; p 0.05). Neonatal lung redox potential was oxidized by deficiencies and PN, but corrected in PNþglutathione (Def:-206AE2; PN:-203AE3; PNþglutathione:-215AE2; Controls:-215AE2 mV; p 0.05). Adult redox potential was reduced in deficient groups, compared to controls (Def:-212AE1; Controls:-206AE2 mV; p 0.05). Conclusion: Neonatal ascorbate and cysteine deficiencies program a pulmonary reduced environment, whereas PN programs higher glutathione levels (GSH and GSSG). Observed perturbations at adulthood are opposite to those at neonatal age.

body_text.text: Vitor Teixeira, Cl emence Guiraut, Jean-Claude Lavoie Department of Nutrition, Research Centre of the CHU Ste-Justine, University of Montreal, Canada Peroxide contamination, ascorbate and cysteine deficiencies are possible causes of parenteral nutrition (PN)-induced liver metabolic programming. We investigated the short-and long-term impacts of neonatal PN (þ/-glutathione i.e. antiperoxide) and ascorbate or cysteine deficient diets over hepatic glutathione and energy metabolism. Methods: Three-day-old guinea pigs received: 1) PN; 2) PNþglutathione (6-12μM); 3) Ascorbate-deficient diet; 4) Cysteine-deficient diet or 5) Complete diets (Controls). Animals were sacrificed after 4 days (neonatal) or at adulthood. Results: Neonatal: Cysteine deficient animals, compared to controls, showed increased (p 0.05) GSSG (1.9AE0.5; 0.6AE0.2 nmol/prot) and redox potential . Glutathione levels are more affected by limited cysteine levels (i.e. decreased GSH synthesis) than by glutathione utilization as anti-peroxide. Glucokinase, phosphofructokinase and acetyl-CoA-carboxylase were modulated (p<0.05) by PN peroxides, as PNþglutathione and deficiency groups were not affected. Adulthood: Neonatal cysteine deficiency, compared to controls, increased GSH (79AE6; 48AE4 nmol/prot) and GSSG (1.3AE0.3; 0.7AE0.1 nmol/prot)(p<0.05). Glucokinase and phosphofructokinase were increased by deficiencies, while acetyl-CoA -carboxylase was increased by PN (p<0.05). Their activities correlate (p<0.05) with GSH (positive) and GSSG (negative), indicating their modulation by glutathione. Conclusion: Neonatal cysteine deficiency reprogrammed glutathione metabolism. PN reprogrammed glutathione and energy metabolism. PNperoxides affect energy metabolism neonatally, but not at adulthood.

body_text.text: 184.24-hydroxycholesterol as Nrf2 activator able to enhance tau clearance for treatment of Alzheimer's disease G. Testa, S. Giannelli, P. Gamba, E. Staurenghi, B. Sottero, G. Poli, G. Leonarduzzi.
body_text.section: 183.Long term metabolic perturbations in liver caused by neonatal nutrition: a focus on redox cues

body_text.text: In recent years, it has become clear that cholesterol dysmetabolism in the brain is involved in Alzheimer's disease (AD) development: it is now believed that cholesterol oxidation products, known as oxysterols, are the link connecting altered brain cholesterol metabolism to AD. Previously, we observed that the cerebrosterol 24-hydroxycholesterol (24-OHC) reduces the accumulation of phosphorylated tau protein upregulating the neuroprotective deacetylase sirtuin 1 (SIRT1) in human neuroblastoma SK-N-BE cells. We are now investigating how the 24-OHC might modulate tau levels. We have shown that 24-OHC, through the activation of the axis SIRT1/ PGC1α/Nrf2, promotes tau deacetylation and ubiquitination, key events leading to tau proteasomal degradation, with the consequent decrease of both phosphorylated and total tau levels. We have demonstrated that 24-OHC, via SIRT-1/PGC1α activation, induces a significant up-regulation of both Nrf2 expression and synthesis. Moreover, 24-OHC leads to a decrease of Nrf2/Keap1 complex inducing a nuclear translocation of Nrf2, with the consequent increase of transcription levels of antioxidant proteins (i.e. HO-1, NQO1) able to counteract oxidative stress. In conclusion, the administration of 24-OHC, as Nrf2 activator, may provide a therapeutic strategy aimed at reducing tau accumulation and oxidative damage, both promising targets in AD prevention.

body_text.text: The reaction of nitrite and secondary amines leads to the formation of stable N-nitrosamines (N-NA), which have been demonstrated to be potent carcinogens. One of the important questions is how N-NA are brought, formed and transmitted from the upper gastrointestinal tract (GI) to the lower GI compartments. We suggest a novel possibility by which proteins and amino acids can function both as nucleophiles and as intermediate substrates to facilitate N-NA formation in situ within the GI tract. Interestingly, the colonic and meat products ambient conditions of pH of about 6.0 and low oxygen levels make the S to N transnitrosation reactions to form N-NA extremely relevant. In the presence of secondary amines and independent of metal catalysis, nucleophiles accelerated N-NA formation from S-nitrosocysteine (Cys-SNO), and that blocking the agonists by targeting either NOX1 (for collagen) or NOX2 (for thrombin). Selective inhibition of either NOX1 or NOX2 impairs the potentiatory effect of tested platelet modulators (oxLDL and Aβ), but does not completely abolish platelet haemostatic function. This information offers new opportunities for the development of disease specific antiplatelet drugs with limited bleeding side effects by selectively targeting NOXs.

body_text.text: 190. Novel NADPH oxidase 1-selective inhibitors impair collagendependent platelet activation and thrombus formation in vitro and ferric chloride-induced carotid occlusion in vivo with negligible effects on thrombin responses and bleeding time Dina Vara 1 , Anuradha Tarafdar , Lorenzo Caggiano , and Giordano Pula The NOX1-selective inhibitor 2-acetyl phenothiazine (2-APT) can inhibit collagen-dependent platelet responses in vitro. We synthesised a series of novel chemical derivatives with improved physicochemical profile compared to 2-APT and tested their ability to affect platelet responses both in vitro and in vivo. Amongst these new compounds, 2APT-PD06, showed the highest in vitro potency as inhibitor of collagen-dependent platelet activation. When administered in mice, 2APT-PD06 inhibited collagen-dependent aggregation in platelet rich plasma (PRP) and thrombus formation under flow in whole blood. Carotid occlusion time was also significantly increased, while tail bleeding time was only marginally affected. The effect of 2APT-PD06 reproduced the functional phenotype observed for genetically silenced NOX1 -/mice (reduced collagen response in vitro and reduced carotid occlusion in vivo). This study describes a novel NOX1 inhibitor able to target collagendependent platelet responses in vitro and carotid occlusion in vivo. The limited effect on thrombin-induced responses in vitro and tail bleeding time in vivo, supports the hypothesis that NOX1 is dispensable for platelet activation in response to thrombin and for the haemostatic response induced by acute vascular injury, while it is essential for collagendependent platelet activation and vascular occlusion induced by endothelial cell damage. The fast-expansion of studies on ferroptosis have highlighted inhibition of the xCT transporting subunit of the cystine-glutamate antiporter (x csystem) as a potent ferroptosis-inducer for anticancer therapy. We investigated this concept by knocking out the xCT subunit in PDAC cell lines (Capan-2 and MiaPaCa-2) using the CRISPR/Cas9 technique.

body_text.text: xCT-KO cells exhibited markedly reduced GSH content, which was further reflected in the prompt accumulation of lipid peroxides, compromised survival, and finally higher sensitivity to chemotherapeutic agents, when compared to wt counterparts. As expected cultivating, xCT-KO cells under reducing conditions (N-acetyl-cysteine or β-mercaptoethanol), which favors uptake of the reduced cysteine form and bypasses the xCT activity, restored GSH content, cell survival and proliferation. Two hallmarks of ferroptotic cell death (lipid peroxide and cell swelling) were also prevented by vitamin E or iron chelation. Interestingly; however, tumor xenograft growth was delayed but not suppressed in xCT-KO cells, which indicated the presence of additional mechanisms for cysteine homeostasis in vivo.

body_text.text: In conclusion, our results suggest that inhibition of xCT, and thereby induction of nutritional and oxidative cellular stresses is a plausible strategy for sensitization of PDAC tumors to ferroptosis. Furthermore, some unwanted resistance mechanisms to xCT inhibition that may be encountered are highlighted.

Adaptation of bEnd.3 brain microvascular endothelial cells to physiological normoxia alters redox signaling and Nrf2regulated antioxidant defences Gabriela Warpsinski 1 , Salil Srivastava , Thomas P. Keeley 1 , Paul A. Fraser 1 , Giovanni E. Mann 1 1 King's British Heart Foundation Centre of Research Excellence, School of Cardiovascular Medicine and Sciences, King's College London, UK.
body_text.section: Department of Clinical and Biological Sciences, University of Torino, San Luigi Hospital, Orbassano, Italy

body_text.text: Most in vitro studies are conducted under room air conditions, however an oxygen gradient exists between the air (~18% O 2 ) and within cells ranging from~13% to~1% O 2 . Consequently, cells cultured under room air conditions are hyperoxic. We reported that long-term culture under 5% O 2 , results in a phenotype different to cultures under 18% O evidenced by downregulation of specific Nrf2 target genes. The phenotype of bEnd.3 microvascular endothelial was characterized following longterm (5 days) culture under 5% (normoxia) or 18% (hyperoxia) O 2 . Using an oxygen sensitive nanoparticle probe (MitoXpress-Intra), the intracellular O 2 level in bEnd.3 cells was 3.6% when cultured under 5% O 2 . Administration of an Nrf2 inducer, sulforaphane (2.5 μM), significantly reduced superoxide burst associated with reperfusion injury in cells cultured initially under 18% O 2 , 1% O 2 (1h) and reoxygenation (18% O 2 ), as measured with L-012 luminescence. Notably, adaptation of bEnd.3 cells to physiological normoxia (5% O 2 ) prevented superoxide production associated with ischaemia-reperfusion injury in cells initially adapted to 18% O 2 . Our findings highlight the importance of conducting vascular cell culture under physiological normoxia to recapitulate the redox phenotype of brain microvascular endothelial cells in vivo. Supported by British Heart Foundation. Age-associated cognitive impairment is a global concern. In the absence of a cure against dementia, preventive lifestyle strategies are highly used. While it is well accepted that multidomain interventions might be more effective than those using nutrition, physical exercise, or cognitive training only, there is still a lack of information on the reciprocal Free Radical Biology and Medicine xxx (xxxx) xxx relationship between nutrition biomarkers and measures of both cognitive and physical performance. We investigated the relationship between plasma levels of nutrition-and antioxidant defense-related biomarkers carotenoids and tocopherols and both indicators of cognitive and physical performance in persons with mild cognitive impairment participating in the JPND NeuroExercise Study at the German Sport University. In 56 participants with full dataset, significant correlations independently of fruit and vegetable intake were found between levels of β-cryptoxanthin and Timed Up&Go test (p< 0.05), of γ-tocopherol and number of daily steps (p< 0.01), as well as between lutein, zeaxanthin, β-cryptoxanthin and β-carotene and the computerized CogState International Shopping List subtest (p < 0.01). In light of the increasing attention towards the nutritional cognitive neuroscience of carotenoids, computerized measures of cognitive performance might be further implemented in future studies investigating the effects of lifestyle interventions against cognitive and physical impairment.
body_text.section: Department of Clinical and Biological Sciences, University of Torino, San Luigi Hospital, Orbassano, Italy

body_text.text: Brittany Woodby, Francesca Ferrara, Erika Pambianchi, Alessandra Pecorelli, Giuseppe Valacchi NC State University, Kannapolis, NC, USA.
body_text.section: Redox regulation of antimicrobial peptides

body_text.text: Although exposure to pollutants has been associated with a variety of diseases, environmental pollutants have also been reported to contribute to cutaneous dysfunctional states, such as premature aging, eczema, acne, psoriasis, contact dermatitis, and atopic dermatitis. Pollutantmediated increased oxidative stress is believed to contribute to the development and exacerbation of pre-existing inflammatory skin disorders, but how pollutants contribute to the development/exacerbation of inflammatory skin disorders remains to be characterized. Antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) are small, cationic peptides found in a variety of immune cells and in the skin. Increased levels of AMPs have been detected in inflammatory skin diseases such as psoriasis and atopic dermatitis. Since exposure to pollutants as well as increased AMP levels are associated with the development/progression of inflammatory skin disorders, we hypothesized that exposure to pollutants increases AMP levels in the skin. We observed increased levels of AMPs in keratinocytes in response to ozone exposure. Current studies in our lab are investigating the pathways involved and what the effects of other pollutants are on AMP levels in the skin. Our novel finding suggests that redox regulation of AMPs may affect the development/progression of inflammatory skin disorders, which could enable the development of new therapeutics.
body_text.section: Redox regulation of antimicrobial peptides

body_text.text: Anjaleena Yaseen 1,2 , Tarique Hussain 1,2 , Amjad Hameed 1,2 , Muhammad Shahzad 1,2 , Nasir Mehmood 1,2 1 Animal Sciences Division, Nuclear Institute for Agriculture and Biology (NIAB), Faisalabad, Pakistan Pakistan Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences (PIEAS), Nilore,
body_text.section: Effect of antioxidant enriched diet on reproductive and biochemical parameters during mid-pregnancy in Beetal goats

body_text.text: The aim of this study was to explore the antioxidative effects of Loxidan feed supplementation against accelerated metabolic rate during midpregnancy in Beetal goats. Thirty-two multiparous pregnant Beetal goats were randomly assigned into two groups supplemented group (n¼16) and control group (n¼16). Supplemented group was offered antioxidant enriched diet (Loxidan) at 120mg/kg/head daily during three months of experiment. Loxidan feed analysis revealed that it contains phenolics, flavonoids, antioxidant capacity, carotenoids, lycopenes and ascorbic acids (P>0.05). Blood was sampled every 15 days during mid-pregnancy (60 to 105 days) for the assessment of serum biochemical parameters. Results revealed that it contains total antioxidant activity, lycopenes and total carotenoids were found significantly higher as compared to control group (P<0.05), while total phenolic contents, total flavonoids, ascorbic acid, ascorbate peroxidase, malondialdehyde, superoxide dismutase and catalase remained statistically similar in both supplemented and control groups (P>0.05). Moreover, antioxidant enriched supplementation increased initial kids' weight, daily weight gain, total average weight gain as compared to control group. Overall, results indicated that loxidan supplementation increased the antioxidant status by alleviating oxidative stress and thus improving goat production.
body_text.section: Islamabad, Pakistan

body_text.text: 196. Macrophage accumulation in the brain after trauma is decreased by deficiency of inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) Qin Yang 1 , Yijen Wu 3 , Yuan Gao 1 , Vincent Vagni 1 , Henry Alexander 1 , Lee Ann New 1 , Valerian E. Kagan , Hülya Bayir Dept. of Developmental Biology, Univ. Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA iNOS is constitutively expressed in classically activated M1 macrophages and microglia that are thought be pro-inflammatory. We hypothesized that iNOS deficiency will decrease accumulation of M1 macrophages and microglial after TBI. C57BL/6J (WT) and iNOS KO mice underwent controlled cortical impact (CCI) followed by i.v. administration of micrometer-sized iron oxide particles (MPIO). MRI and brain tissue flow cytometry analysis were performed at 72h and 96h, respectively. MRI showed a significantly larger area of MPIO positivity in injured cerebral cortex and hippocampus of WT vs. iNOS KO. Flow cytometry confirmed phagocytic nature of MPIO containing cells. There was no difference in contusion or edema volume in injured cortex and in MPIO volume in uninjured cortex between groups. M1 macrophages (CD11b þ /CD45hi/ CD86 þ ) and microglia (CD11b þ /CD45 lo /CD86 þ ), and to a lesser degree M2 macrophages (CD11b þ /CD45 hi / CD206 þ ) and microglia (CD11b þ / CD45 lo / CD206 þ ) were decreased in pericontusional cortex/hippocampus in iNOS KO vs WT after CCI. There was no difference between groups for uninjured cortex/hippocampus. iNOS deficiency decreases monocyte derived macrophage and microglia recruitment into pericontusional area. Given the fact that genetic deficiency or pharmacological inhibition of iNOS worsens outcome after TBI, these data suggest that recruitment of monocyte derived macrophages and microglia into contusion is likely beneficial.

body_text.text: Yunjia Zhang 1,2 , Mathias Jensen 3 , Benjamin Rayner 1,2 , Clare Hawkins 3 1 Heart Research Institute, Australia; 2 University of Sydney, Australia; 3 University of Copenhagen, Denmark.
body_text.section: Release of extracellular traps by macrophages under chronic inflammatory conditions

body_text.text: The production of extracellular traps (ETs) by neutrophils in response to inflammatory stimuli, is now recognized to play an important role within a range of chronic disease settings, including driving lesion development in atherosclerosis. ETs consist of mesh of DNA, histones, myeloperoxidase and proteolytic enzymes, which are involved in bacterial killing. However, ETs also promote inflammation and contribute to pathological processes, including atherosclerosis. The aim of this study was to examine whether macrophages also release ETs on exposure to inflammatory stimuli, because these cells play a critical role in the development of atherosclerosis. We show that exposure of human monocyte-derived macrophages to HOCl results in the dose-dependent extrusion of DNA and histones into the cellular supernatant, consistent with ET formation. Unlike neutrophils, ET release from HMDM occurs independently of histone citrullination, but does involve cytosolic accumulation of calcium. Polarisation of the macrophages prior to HOCl exposure revealed a greater propensity for inflammatory M1 macrophages and not alternatively-activated M2 macrophages, to produce ETs. M1 macrophages also produced ETs on exposure to other inflammatory stimuli, including interleukin-8 and tumour necrosis factor α. These data indicate a potential role for macrophage ET formation during chronic inflammation, which could be relevant for atherosclerosis.
body_text.section: Release of extracellular traps by macrophages under chronic inflammatory conditions

body_text.text: 198.Stimulation of adrenergic receptors in cardiac myoblasts activates Nox-2 which initiates downstream redox-signal Anamika and S.K.Goswami School of Life Sciences, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, India Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are an essential constituent of adrenergic signalling in cardiac myocytes. Despite its relevance in the cardiovascular pathophysiology, the source(s) of ROS, its nature and function have not been explored yet. We have investigated the mechanism of ROS generation upon activation of αand β-ARs in H9c2 and reconstituted HEK293 cells. Adrenergic stimulation induced DCFH-DA sensitive ROS and its level was more when they were added separately as compared to respective combinations of agonists and antagonists. In all the cases, H2O2 was generated in the cytosol and superoxide in the mitochondria. The role of NOX2 in ROS generation was demonstrated by its selective inhibition by the peptide gp91-ds-tat. The activation of NOX2 was confirmed by immunocytochemistry and the membrane translocation of the p47-Phox subunit. Its effect on the downstream signalling and gene expression was assayed by immunoblotting and promoter-reporter assay. ROS generated by all the agonists and antagonists regulated downstream gene expression in a similar but distinctive manner. Thus, generation of ROS is an integral part of signalling by the αand β-adrenoreceptors.

back_matter.text: Department of Dermatology and Allergy, University of Ulm, Ulm, Germany.Reactive oxygen species are important contributors to melanoma growth and metastatic propensity. Melanoma originates from skin melanocytes, rapidly metastasizes due to modulation of various kinase-based signal transduction pathways. Some of the involved signal transduction proteins are activated by reactive oxygen species and phosphorylation: they mediate signals for proliferation and migration of melanoma cells. In this study, we explored the potential of a newly synthesized and fully characterized novel bis-coumarin derivative as a potential anti-melanoma, anti-metastatic agent by utilizing various human malignant cell lines. To this end, we have used a "four-focus area strategy" to evaluate the biscoumarin derivative (i) cytotoxicity against various metastatic and nonmetastatic melanoma cell lines, and its effect on non-cancerous cell lines, (ii) inhibition of melanoma cell migration (iii) inhibition of melanoma cell proliferation (iv) potential to modulate ROS dependent and independent kinase-mediated signaling cascades. It appears that this and similar bis-coumarins derivatives could be used to control kinase phosphorylation with the aim to prevent, and/or treat, melanoma with minimal unwanted side effects.Although many plant-derived antioxidants can exert an important role in several disease therapy and prevention, usually unfavourable physicochemical features compromise their use. The emulsification of glyceryl monooleate in water in the presence of surfactants gives rise to the formation of nanostructured lipid dispersions suitable for solubilization and delivery of low soluble active molecules. At this regard, in this study crocin and curcumin have been solubilized and loaded within nanostructured lipid dispersions designed to treat skin inflammatory conditions. The use of poloxamer, sodium cholate or sodium caseinate as stabilizers resulted in dispersions constituted of cubosomes, hexasomes, sponge systems or vesicles, as detected by cryogenic transmission electron microscopy. Franz cell studies demonstrated the suitability of nanostructured lipid dispersions to control crocin and curcumin permeation through the skin, while shelf life tests evidenced their capability to retard antioxidant degradation. Notably, the oxygen radical absorbance capacity assay pointed out that both crocin and curcumin prolonged their antioxidant activity when loaded in nanostructured lipid dispersions. Furthermore, the MTT test evidenced that the nanostructures increased crocin antiproliferative activity towards a human melanoma cell line, while Western blot analysis, performed to evaluate the inhibitory effect of nanoencapsulated curcumin towards iNOS expression, demonstrated a prolonged antioxidant/antinflammatory activity. 2-Hexadecenal (2HD)a biologically active aldehyde, which level can rise under oxidative stress conditions. A number of processes leading to the formation of 2HD from sphingolipids have been established to date: biochemical cleavage of sphingosine-1-phosphate, photochemical destruction of sphingomyelin, as well as ROS and HOCl-induced fragmentation of sphingosine. A wide range of reactions leading to the accumulation of 2HD in biosystems motivates to study its properties. It has been shown that 2HD inhibits growth of C6 glioma cells due to modification of intracellular processes of signal transduction, cytoskeleton rearrangement, change in the mitotic regimen and apoptosis induction. These effects are associated with modification of cells' redox activity. In the early stages of interaction with cells, 2HD increases the production of superoxide anion radicals by mitochondria and decreases the intracellular level of reduced glutathione. Cells treatment with 2HD for 24 h causes a significant increase in ROS production due to activation of cytosol enzymes including stress-activated MAPK. Since HOCl hyper production in the brain occurs in a number of pathologies associated with the development of inflammation (neurodegeneration, stroke, cancer) 2HD can be considered as a new marker of oxidative stress.

Bachuki Shashikadze 1,2 , Marta Grzechowiak , Mariusz Jaskolski 1,3 , Bronislaw Marciniak 1,2 , Marta Ignasiak Kciuk 1,21 Adam Mickiewicz University, Faculty of Chemistry, Poznan, Poland 2 Center for Advanced Technologies, Pozna n, Poland 3 Institute of Bioorganic Chemistry, Polish Academy of Sciences, Poznan,
back_matter.section: Iodide prevents proteins from oxidative damage. From traditional biochemical methods to crystallographic tools

back_matter.text: Iodide is an essential micronutrient for all living organisms. In the process of oxidative stress iodide can have a protective or damaging effect that will influence the fate of oxidative protein modification. In this study we have investigated the mechanism of oxidation of lysozyme and several cytokinin-specific binding proteins from plants by HOCl in the presence of iodide ions, in order to characterize whole scenario from harmlessness to hazardous level of iodide in oxidative stress. Results obtained from SDS-PAGE, chromatography, mass spectrometry and western blot show inhibition of protein aggregation associated to e.g. prevention of dityrosine formation as a result of iodination of tyrosine. In addition, enzymatic and binding assays were applied to observe the effect of iodide on the activity of proteins. X-ray diffraction will be used to study. Quinones are a common motif in many biological compounds, and can react with nucleophiles, such as protein cysteine (Cys) residues via Michael addition reactions. The selenyl anion of selenocysteine (Sec) is a stronger nucleophile and more reactive than the thiol group of Cys. We therefore hypothesized that Sec residues should be modified by quinones and affect selenoprotein structure and function. This was investigated using p-benzoquinone (BQ) and the selenoproteins, thioredoxin reductase (TrxR) and glutathione peroxidase (GPx). Incubation of purified proteins, cell lysates, or intact J774A.1 cells, with BQ resulted in a rapid and concentration-dependent loss of TrxR, but not GPx enzymatic activity. BQ also induced a concentration-dependent dimerization of TrxR but not GPx. Further experiments indicated that BQ modifies the Sec and Cys residues of both TrxR and GPx in a partly-reversible manner, with glutathione (GSH) able to prevent (by competitive reaction with BQ) or reverse (by S-glutathionylation) the loss of enzyme activity and dimerization of TrxR. GSH is a co-factor for GPx, explaining the lack of inhibition of GPx by BQ. These data suggested that BQ could selectively and reversibly modify Sec residues of selenoproteins, but the downstream consequences were dependent on the protein structure and its catalytic mechanism.

Free Radical Biology and Medicine xxx (xxxx) xxx primary amine residue of Cys-SNO significantly delays reactivity toward N-NA formation and enterocytes carcinogenicity (DNA methylation in the presence of secondary amines). For the first time we propose that this nucleophile dependent pathway is involved in generation of N-NA in the presence of secondary amines. Due to S to N transnitrosation these compounds can form the unusable highly reactive intermediates that will generate N-NA by direct reactions. Oxidative stress is one of the main factors in the onset and progression of some hepatic, cardiovascular and renal diseases. It is well known that the master gene in the regulation of the cellular antioxidant response is the Nuclear factor (erythroid-derived 2)-like 2 (Nrf2). In this work, we evaluate the effect of Croton hypoleucus (EC), known as "Palo blanco" (native shrub of Hidalgo, M exico), on Nrf2 and catalase expression, in a thioacetamide (TAA) induced liver damage model, to find out the probable mechanism of the hepatoprotective activity previously found by our group in EC extract against acute damage by TAA. Four groups were established: EC, TAA, EC TAA and a Control group. For EC TAA, wistar rats (6 weeks old) were intragastrically pre-administered for 4 days with EC (300 mg/day) and the last day a single dose (400 mg/kg) of TAA (i.p.). At 24 h after of damage induction, animals were sacrificed. Liver homogenate was used to evaluate mRNA expression by qRT-PCR protocols. The results showed that EC TAA group did not enhance the gene expression of Nrf2, while catalase maintained its levels closer to control in the same group. Therefore, EC has antioxidant effect no dependent of Nrf2 pathway. The superoxide anion production by cytochrome b 5 reductase (Cb 5 R) can be stimulated by cytochrome c 1,2 , but very little is known about other potential activators of this production by Cb 5 R. A drug screening against the NADH:ferricyanide reductase activity of recombinant human erythrocyte enzyme allowed us to find that 5-hydroxy-1,4-naphthoquinone was able to inhibit the reduction of ferricyanide by Cb 5 R. A further characterization of the system showed that 5-hydroxy-1,4-naphthoquinone was indeed able to act as an electron acceptor of the reductase and promote the formation of superoxide anion. Our results allow us to rationalize the toxic effect of this compound in eryptosis and further reveal Cb 5 R as an overseen target, in cellular conditions, inducing oxidative stress 3 . References The regulation of platelets by oxidants is critical for vascular health and may explain thrombotic complications in diseases such as diabetes and vascular dementia, but remains poorly understood. Using selective peptide inhibitors of NADPH oxidases (NOXs) on human platelets and genetically modified mouse platelets (NOX1 -/or NOX2 -/-), we discovered that: 1) intracellular but not extracellular superoxide anion generated by NOXs is critical for platelet activation by collagen; 2) superoxide dismutation to hydrogen peroxide is required for thrombindependent activation; 3) NOX1 is the main source of oxygen radicals in response to collagen, while NOX2 is critical for activation by thrombin; 4) oxidised low density lipoproteins (oxLDL) and amyloid peptide β (Aβ), two modulators of platelets associated with vascular complications of hyperlipidemia and dementia, require contemporaneous activation of NOX1 and NOX2 to pre-activate platelets. FIGREF17.text: 95. Trx/TrxR system in redox-dependent regulation under development of cisplatin resistance in cancer cells Elena Kalinina 1 , Yaroslav Andreev 2 , Albina Petrova 1 , Alexander Shtil 3 , Nikolai Chernov 1 , Maria Novichkova 1 . Blokhin National Medical Research Center of Oncology, Moscow, Russian Federation Trx/TrxR-regulatory redox pathways may be the significant part of key events in the stress response and/or resetting redox homeostasis resulted in the change of most vital functions of cells, including proliferation, differentiation, apoptosis. Here we studied a level of Trx/TrxR activity and cellular redox-dependent changes during the development of resistance in human ovarian carcinoma SKOV-3 cells to cisplatin that possesses prooxidant effect. Increase of TRX1, TRXDR1, TRXDR2 gene expression as well as Trx and TrxR activity was found under formation of cancer cell resistance. The alteration of Trx/TrxR system was detected together with a change of the balance ROS/antioxidants in favor of growth of antioxidant state due to increase of key antioxidant enzymes gene expression (SOD2, CAT, GPX1, HO-1) and decrease of NADPH oxidase (NOX5) expression. Apoptosis suppression and much smaller extent of ASK1 and JNK1 phosphorylation were observed in resistant SKOV3/ CDDP cells in contrast to the wild cells under H2O2 treatment. The results testify in favor of the important role of Trx/TrxR system in the rise of adaptive antioxidant response under formation of cisplatin resistance in cancer cells. FIGREF48.text: Medicine, Institute of Experimental Pharmacology & Toxicology, Slovak Academy of Sciences, Bratislava, SlovakiaAgeing is coupled with long-term impairment of redox homeostasis, what leads to development of chronic oxidative stress conditions and inflammation, especially in cells of CNS. In environment of chronic inflammation, microglia (cells of immune system in CNS) are immunologically activated and contribute themselves to increased neuroinflammation. Moreover, cellular senescence is a process critically participating in ageing, characterised by loss of proliferation, alterations in mitochondrial and lysosomal functions and defects in autophagy. All mentioned processes are responsible for propagation of age-related diseases. Electrophilic compounds have shown positive effect as therapeutic approach in restoration of imbalanced redox homeostasis and developed inflammation because of their capability to induce nucleophilic status of the cell by activation of defensive molecular mechanisms and thus supress oxidative conditions. Our study investigates efficacy of synthetic flavonoid derivative, 4-O-(2-chloro-1,4-naphtoquinone-3-yloxy) quercetin (CHNQ) at sub-toxic and non-damaging concentration to mitigate activation of microglia as well as to downregulate senescence hallmarks in replicative senescent human fibroblasts. CHNQ in LPS-activated microglia downregulated pro-inflammatory markers (TNFα, NO, COX-2) and modulated antioxidant response (Nrf2) via TLR4/HO-I pathway. In longterm cultivation of human fibroblasts, CHNQ showed positive effect on mitochondria and lysosomes along with improvement of autophagy parameters [VEGA 2/0041/17, APVV-15-0308, APVV-18-0336].173. TABREF23.text: S), a toxic gaseous molecule, acts as cell-signalling factor in the central nervous system to maintain balanced amounts of antioxidants and combat oxidative species. However, H S can have a double biological action switching from neuromodulator to a neurotoxic agent when present at noxious levels. Furthermore, H S mediates the formation of cysteine persulfides (R-S-SH), which affect the activity of target proteins. The biological reactivity of the sulphur atom in cysteine is a significant factor in determining susceptibility to oxidative damage and neurodegeneration. It is thus important that H 2 S is maintained at physiological levels through a right balance between H S synthesis and breakdown. Our studies showed aberrant H 2 S levels in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS). H 2 S, mainly produced by glial cells, is extremely toxic to motor neurons and increases Ca 2þ intracellular concentration. In primary spinal cord cultures from ALS mouse model SOD1 G93A , H 2 S increases glialrelated toxicity, decreasing ATP production and mitochondrial respiration rate and promoting the activation of oxidative and nitrosativerelated pathways. Its modulation can reduce glial mediated pathology and ameliorate mitochondrial homeostasis. On these evidences, H 2 S is proposed as one of the toxic mediators released by glial cells that participates in the non-cell autonomous-mediated death observed in ALS.82. TABREF26.text: We have shown that NO inhibits complex III, increasing [UQH • ] ss , [cyt. b 2þ ], and O 2•and H 2 O 2 production rates. This work investigated the interaction of NO with complex III using a complex III enriched fraction -isolated from bovine heart-and NO solution (obtained by bubbling NO; 10% in N 2 ), in order to characterize the inhibition of electron transfer and the consequences on O 2 •production, and to postulate a kinetic mechanism that explains the experimental results. Complex III exposed to NO showed a hyperbolic inhibition of decylubiquinol:cytochrome c reductase activity (IC 50 ¼225 nM) and the characteristic peak of cyt. b H 2þ , suggesting the interaction of NO with the hemo b 562 . According to [UQH • ] ss enhancement detected by EPR, H O 2 production rate was augmented (55%) in coupled mitochondria exposed to 1 μM NO. Dietary nitrate and nitrite represent alternative substrates for nitric
oxide (NO) generation and stimulation of the nitrate-nitrite-NO
pathway reduces oxidative stress and enhances mitochondrial effi-
ciency. This makes nitrate and nitrite an appealing dietary-based
intervention to address age-related disorders, where NO availability
is diminished.

dams show improved gestational weight gain from gestational day 7 to
18. 125. Red blood cell-derived microparticles and oxidative stress
intermediates in erythrocytes of pregnant women with
preeclampsia and hypertension
L.E. Muravlyova, V.B. Molotov-Luchanskiy, R.E. Bakirova, O.A. Pona-
mareva, D.A. Kluyev, D.E. Omertayeva.
Karaganda Medical University, Kazakhstan
The purpose of investigation was to study the ability of erythrocytes to
form microparticles and the changes of oxidized derivatives levels in red
blood cells (RBCs) in pregnant women. There were 64 pregnant women
divided into 2 groups. 1st group was represented by 35 pregnant women
with preeclampsia and hypertension (which had been before and had
been continuing during pregnancy); the 2nd group -by 29 pregnant
women with hypertension only. The control group consisted of 15
healthy persons. In RBCs the concentrations of the reactive protein
carbonyl derivatives (RPCDs), membrane bound hemoglobin, methyl-
glyoxal and the ability of RBCs to form microvesicles were evaluated. In
RBCs of patients of 1 group all oxidative stress intermediates were sig-
nificant increased. In RBCs of patients of 2 group the RPCDs was elevated
only. The amount of microparticles formed from RBCs in patients of 1 st
and 2 nd groups was significantly higher than in control by 2.6 times and
by 2 times respectively. Our results demonstrate that the accumulation of
oxidative stress intermediates in RBCs of 1st group patients may be
connected with increased ability of RBCs to form microvesicles, that
could be discussed as playing important role in pathogenesis of
preeclampsia.

Gestational diabetes and obesity predispose mothers and offspring to-
wards long-term cardiometabolic dysfunction. Sulforaphane (SFN), a
dietary isothiocyanate, is a well-known activator of the endogenous Nrf2
Infectiology and Immunology, Institute of Immunology, Medical Uni-

TABREF36.text: Our preliminary findings also indicate SFN supplementation improves glucose tolerance in dams following acute glucose challenge (GTT 2g/kg 0-120min MeanAES.E.M AUC Pre-pregnancy 23.34AE8.82mmol vs. Post-weaning 18.64AE2.99mmol). Furthermore, SFN treated dams showed trends towards reduced brown adipose tissue mass (Veh 0.0126AE0.0003g vs SFN 0.0093AE0.0008g) and reduced subcutaneous inguinal fat pad mass (Veh 0.096AE0.002g vs SFN 0.078AE0.011g) relative to tibia length. Taken together these findings suggest that SFN may improve the metabolic phenotype of dams when given during pregnancy and weaning.

TABREF39.content:
133. Multifunctional platinum@bsa¡rapamycin nanocarriers for
combinatorial therapy of cerebral cavernous malformation
disease
A. Perrelli, E. De Luca, D. Pedone, M. Moglianetti, C. Fornelli, A. Zotta, D.
Pulcini, P.P. Pompa, S.F. Retta.
Department of Clinical and Biological Sciences, Torino, Italy, Center for
Biomolecular Nanotechnologies, Lecce, Italy, Department of Engineering
for Innovation, Lecce, Italy.
Platinum nanoparticles (PtNPs) are nanomaterials known to act as arti-
ficial antioxidant enzymes (nanozymes) and endowed with significant
potential for the treatment of complex diseases related to oxidative stress.
Among such diseases, Cerebral Cavernous Malformation (CCM) is a
major cerebrovascular disorder of proven genetic origin, affecting 0.5%
of the general population and causing major clinical symptoms, such
seizures, focal neurological deficits, and hemorrhagic stroke. Accumu-
lated evidence from our laboratory demonstrates that loss-of-function
mutations of any of the three known CCM genes (KRIT1/CCM1, CCM2
and CCM3) predispose endothelial cells to oxidative stress-mediated
dysfunctions by affecting intracellular redox homeostasis and distinct
redox-sensitive signaling pathways and mechanisms, including pro-
oxidant and antioxidant pathways and autophagy. As a multitargeted
combinatorial therapy approach for proper restoring cellular redox ho-
meostasis and signaling in cellular and animal models of CCM disease, we
developed a multifunctional nanocarrier that combines the radical
scavenging activity of PtNPs with the autophagy-stimulating activity of
rapamycin. Our results show that the combinatorial targeting of redox
signaling and autophagy dysfunctions is effective in rescuing major
molecular and cellular hallmarks of CCM disease, including altered redox
homeostasis and endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EndMt), sug-
gesting its high potential for the treatment of this and other oxidative
stress-related diseases.
134. Profile of pathogenic proteins in total circulating
extracellular vesicles in mild cognitive impairment and during
the progression of Alzheimer's disease
Morgane Perrotte; Mohamed Haddad; Aur elie Le Page; Tam as Ful€ op and
Charles RamassamyUraiwan Panich, Nilar Win Htut, Somponnant Sampattavanich
INRS-Institut Armand-Frappier, Laval, Canada.Department of Pharmacology, Faculty of Medicine Siriraj Hospital,
Mahidol University, Bangkok, Thailand
Nuclear factor E2-related factor 2 (Nrf2) is a master regulator of anti-
oxidant defense against environmental insults including UV radiation.
We previously reported that Nrf2 plays a beneficial role in regulating
cellular response of keratinocytes and melanocytes to UV-induced
oxidative damage. Plant-derived phytochemicals targeting Nrf2 have
also been shown to represent a promising pharmacological strategy for
inhibition of skin photoaging. This study thus aimed to develop an
innovative Nrf2 biosensor in live cells in order to monitor Nrf2 activity in
the skin cells in response to different stimuli and to assess Nrf2 inducing
TABREF39.text: Nrf2 activities in real time. Moreover, Nrf2 biosensor developed in our study can be employed to screen candidate compounds for further development of effective anti-aging agents.
